{{More footnotes|date=September 2010}} {{Autobiography|date=September 2010}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Alasdair White |birth_date = May 24, 1952 |birth_place = [[England]] |death_date = |death_place = |residence = [[Belgium]] |citizenship = |nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] |ethnicity = |field = [[Behavioural psychology]] |work_institutions = |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[Performance management]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Alasdair Antony Kenneth White''' (born May 24, 1952) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] management theorist best known for his work on [[performance management]] from a behavioural perspective and in the field of deconcentrated and networked organizations. Along with John Fairhurst, White developed the White-Fairhurst Performance Hypothesis relating to the performance life-cycle. He is also the author of ''Continuous Quality Improvement'' and ''The Essential Guide to Developing Your Staff''.
==Research== In 2006, he worked closely with John Fairhurst and, following various observational studies, they formulated the White-Fairhurst Performance Hypothesis which states that "all performance will initially trend towards a steady state, particularly after a period of performance uplift, and that steady state will then develop a downward curve leading to a significant performance decline".
[[File:White-Fairhurst TPR Model.jpg|thumb|250px|right|White-Fairhurst TPR Model<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pm-solutions.com/ComfortZone_Performance.html |title=From Comfort Zone to Performance Management |last=Alasdair |first=White |date=November 2009 |publisher=Performance Management Solutions |accessdate=29 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421085837/http://www.pm-solutions.com/ComfortZone_Performance.html |archivedate=21 April 2010 }}</ref>]] In a paper entitled ''From Comfort Zone to Performance Management'', White examines the hypothesis from a theoretical perspective starting with the [[Comfort Zone Theory]] and the work of [[Robert Yerkes]] and John Dodson, David McClelland et al., the [[Tuckman Model]] and Colin Carnall. This theoretical examination leads White to conclude that the White-Fairhurst Hypothesis broadly holds true and the performance curve is as demonstrated in the White-Fairhurst TPR Life-cycle Model (TPR stands for Transforming, Performing, Reforming). There has been some criticism of White’s approach, suggesting that more recent sources and work would have been more appropriate, but none have been able to offer a counter-argument or to adequately refute or dispute the hypothesis. The fact remains that most of the fundamentals of performance behaviour were established in the last century and that the more recent work is itself based on this earlier work.
White argues that what is important now is to determine trend-change points on the performance curve so that the most appropriate performance management actions can be applied. He conducted research within a university environment in this relation to this and the result is recorded in his 2008 essay ''Managing Academic Performance'' the underlying theory of which underpins the approach being adopted by a number of academic institutions.
==Writing== In addition to writing on management issues, White is also active in writing and editing fiction for White & MacLean Publishing. Among those writings include the a political and action novel ''Shadows'', written under the pen-name of Alex Hunter.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== *Carnall, C. – Managing Change in Organizations, 1995, Prentice Hall *McClelland, D.C., Atkinson, J.W., Clark, R.A., & Lowell, E.L. (1953) – The achievement motive, 1953, Princeton: Van Nostrand *Tuckman, Bruce W. – ‘Developmental Sequence in Small Groups’, 1965, Psychological Bulletin, Volume 63, Number 6, pp. 384 99, American Psychological Association *White A. – ‘From Comfort Zone to Performance Management’. 2008 {{ISBN|978-2-930583-01-3}}. White & MacLean Publishing *Yerkes, R., & Dodson, J. – ‘The Dancing Mouse, A Study in Animal Behavior’, 1907, Journal of Comparative Neurology & Psychology, Number 18, pp. 459–482
==Further reading== *''Managing for Performance'' London 1995 Piatkus Books *''Continuous Quality Improvement'' London 1996 Piatkus Books *''The Essential Guide to Developing Your Staff'' London 1998 Piatkus Books *''[https://web.archive.org/web/20081204021059/http://www.pm-solutions.com/newreality.html Performance Management – A New Reality]'' 2000 on the PM-Solutions website *''[http://www.whiteandmaclean.eu/from-comfort-zone-to-performance-management/From Comfort Zone to Performance Management]'' 2008 {{ISBN|978-2-930583-01-3}}. White & MacLean Publishing *''Managing Academic Performance'' 2008 White & MacLean Publishing
==External links== *[http://www.pm-solutions.com PM-Solutions] *[http://www.ubi.edu United Business Institutes] *[http://www.emadin.com European Management Development Institute] *[http://www.napoleonicsociety.com/ International Napoleonic Society] *[http://www.whiteandmaclean.eu White & MacLean Publishing]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:White, Alasdair}} [[Category:Researchers]] [[Category:British business theorists]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Winchester]] [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

Founded in Paris in 1971, '''Analyse Financière''' also known as '''Revue Analyse Financière''' is one of Europe’s longest running financial research quarterlies, with contributions from leading academics and financial industry professionals as well as policy makers and national and international regulators.
The ''Revue'' is published by the [[French Society of Financial Analysts]] (SFAF), France's National Association of Financial Analysts that brings together [[investment banking]], [[private equity]] and [[asset management]] experts and researchers focusing on [[securities]] valuation, [[capital markets]] and [[financial economics]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.sfaf.com SFAF website] * [http://www.revueanalysefinanciere.com Revue Analyse Financière website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Analyse Financiere}} [[Category:Finance journals]] [[Category:Analyst societies]] [[Category:Financial regulation]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}}{{Use South African English|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox officeholder | honorific_prefix = | name = Andrew Feinstein | honorific_suffix = | image = Andrew Feinstein.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> | alt = | caption = Feinstein at the presentation of the documentary "Shadow World: Inside the Global Arms Trade" in Copenhagen 2016 | order = | office = [[Member of the National Assembly of South Africa]] | term_start = 1994 | term_end = 2001 <!-- Personal life --> | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|3|16|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Cape Town]], South Africa | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | citizenship = South Africa | nationality = | party = [[African National Congress]] | otherparty = <!--For additional political affiliations--> | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | spouse = {{marriage|Simone Sultana|1993}} | partner = <!--For those with a domestic partner and not married--> | relations = | children = Three | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | relatives = | residence = [[London]], England | education = | alma_mater = {{plain list| * [[King's College, Cambridge]] * [[University of California, Berkeley]] * [[University of Cape Town]] }} | occupation = | profession = | known_for = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | awards = }} '''Andrew Josef Feinstein''' (born 16 March 1964) is a former [[South African]] politician who currently resides in the [[United Kingdom]], but remains a South African citizen.
==Personal life== He was born in [[Cape Town]] to Ralph Josef Feinstein and Erika Hemmer. He graduated from [[Wynberg Boys' High School]] in 1981, and received further education at [[King's College, Cambridge]], the [[University of California at Berkeley]] and the [[University of Cape Town]]. He married Simone Sultana on 18 December 1993, and has a son and a daughter. His interests include reading, classical & jazz music, cinema, theatre, watching rugby, cricket & soccer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.whoswhosa.co.za/andrew-feinstein-3673|title=Andrew Feinstein {{!}} Who's Who SA|website=www.whoswhosa.co.za|language=en|access-date=2018-01-03}}</ref>
==Political life== A member of the [[African National Congress]] (ANC), his political life began when he served as an advisor to [[Gauteng]]'s then-MEC of Finance, [[Jabu Moleketi]], from 1994 to 1996. He also worked as an economic advisor to then-premier [[Tokyo Sexwale]]. He was elected as a member of the [[Parliament of South Africa|South African Parliament]]'s [[National Assembly of South Africa|lower house]] in 1997.
During his time in office, he served as chair of its study group on public accounts and ANC's official spokesman on the [[National Assembly of South Africa|National Assembly]]'s public accounts committee. Feinstein was at the time referred to as "one of its most vocal and talented MPs", who argued that a thorough investigation into the [[South African Arms Deal]] had to be done.<ref>[http://70.84.171.10/~etools/newsbrief/2001/news0130.txt ''ANC seeks to play down Feinstein demotion'', SAPA, 29 February 2001.]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> However, he resigned in 2001 when the ANC refused to launch an investigation into the matter.<ref>[http://www.anc.org.za/ancdocs/pr/2001/pr0830c.html ''Statement by Andrew Feinstein MP'' - 30 August 2001] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090323082152/http://www.anc.org.za/ancdocs/pr/2001/pr0830c.html |date=23 March 2009 }}</ref> He was succeeded by [[Geoff Doidge]] in both positions.
==Immigration to the UK== He now resides in [[London]], where he chairs the Aids charity Friends of the [[Treatment Action Campaign]], and lectures and writes on South Africa. He also works as a Securities Coordinator for [[Investec Bank]] UK Ltd.
He is now considered an ANC dissident and critic, with his memoirs, ''After the Party'', being severely critical of the political culture of the ANC.
In an interview with ''[[Democracy Now!]]'', he noted the ways in which the global arms trade was linked to the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.democracynow.org/2012/12/26/as_us_faces_gun_epidemic_post |title=As U.S. Faces Gun Epidemic Post-Newtown, Obama Urged to Break With NRA & Back Global U.N. Arms Treaty |date=26 December 2012}}</ref>
In 2011 Feinstein published ''The Shadow World'', an investigation into the global [[arms industry]]. He reported "that the [[Arms industry|trade in weapons]] accounts for around 40 percent of all corruption in all world trade The .. trade in weapons is extremely closely tied into the mechanics of government. The defence manufacturers, those who make the weapons, are closely tied in to governments, to militaries, to intelligence agencies and crucially to political parties."<ref>{{cite news |title= Is society inherently corrupt? A look at the global arms industry and the effect corruption has on our politics, society and culture. |author= South to North |url= http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/south2north/2013/01/2013118151914861779.html |newspaper= Al Jazeera English |publisher= Al Jazeera |accessdate= 19 January 2013 }}</ref>
==Books== *''After the Party: A Personal and Political Journey Inside the ANC''<ref name="Feinstein2007">{{cite book|author=Andrew Feinstein|title=After the party: a personal and political journey inside the ANC|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xvgVAQAAIAAJ|year=2007|publisher=Jonathan Ball|isbn=978-1-86842-262-3}}</ref> *''The Shadow World: Inside the Global Arms Trade.''<ref name="Feinstein2011">{{cite book|author=Andrew Feinstein|title=The Shadow World: Inside the Global Arms Trade|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u06m3epox7wC|year=2011|publisher=Hamish Hamilton|isbn=978-0-241-14441-1}}</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== *[https://www.theguardian.com/profile/andrewfeinstein Profile of and editorials by Feinstein] on [[The Guardian]]
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox person | name = Anthony Joseph Drexel Jr. | image = Anthony Joseph Drexel, Jr. (1865–1934) and Margarita Armstrong on December 29, 1916.jpg | caption = Drexel, and his wife, Marjorie, 1916 | birth_date = {{birth date|1864|09|09}} | birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1934|12|14|1864|09|09}} | death_place = | occupation = [[Banker]] | spouse = {{marriage|Armstrong
|September 14, 1886|May 25, 1917|reason=div}} | parents = [[Anthony Joseph Drexel]]
Ellen B. Rozet | children = 2 | relatives = [[Alexander Van Rensselaer]] (brother-in-law)
[[Francis Anthony Drexel]] (uncle)
[[Joseph William Drexel]] (uncle)
[[Katharine Drexel]] (cousin)
[[Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle Sr.|Anthony Drexel Biddle Sr.]] (cousin)
[[Francis Martin Drexel]] (grandfather) }} '''Anthony Joseph "Tony" Drexel Jr.''' (September 9, 1864 – December 14, 1934) was an American banker and philanthropist who was a close friend of [[Edward VII|King Edward VII]]. ==Early life== Drexel was born on September 9, 1864, in [[Philadelphia]] to [[Anthony Joseph Drexel]] (1826–1893) and Ellen Rozet (1832–1891). He was one of nine children, including: Emilie Taylor Drexel (1851–1883),{{cite news |title= The Theater: New Plays in Manhattan |date= December 3, 1956 |work= [[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]] |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,866393,00.html |accessdate= March 17, 2011 }}{{cite news |author= |title=Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Dead. Ambassador to Spain Was 64. Envoy and Officer in World War II. Tributes Paid by Kennedy and Eisenhower |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1961/11/14/archives/anthony-j-drexel-biddle-dead-ambassador-to-spain-was-64-envoy-and.html |quote=Anthony J. Drexel Biddle, ambassador to Spain and for many years one of this country's most distinguished diplomats, died today at Walter Reed Army ... |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 14, 1961 |accessdate= April 10, 2010 }} Frances Katherine Drexel (1852–1892), Mae E. Drexel (1857–1886), Sarah Rozet "Sallie" Drexel (1860–1929), the wife of [[Alexander Van Rensselaer]],{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The Now York|title=A.VAN RENSSELAER, ARTS PATRON, DEAD {{!}} Philadelphia Philanthropist and Sportsman Succumbs to Long Illness at 82. {{!}} PRINCETON LIFE TRUSTEE {{!}} President of the Philadelphia Orchestra Association From 1901 Till Recently.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1933/07/19/archives/ayanrensselaer-arts-patron-dead-v-____________________-philadelphia.html|accessdate=22 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 July 1933}} John Rozet Drexel (1863–1935), and George William Childs Drexel (1868–1944).{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Anthony J. Drexel is Dead. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1893/07/01/archives/anthony-j-drexel-is-dead-philadelphias-great-banker-stricken-with-a.html |quote=News of His Death Sent by Cable from Carlsbad. He Went There in Poor Health to Spend the Summer. Last of the Sons of the Founder of His House. Known All Over the World as a Financier. A Philanthropist as Well. Connected with Many Gigantic Transactions. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 1, 1893 |accessdate=2008-12-23 }} His father was the founder [[Drexel, Morgan & Co.|Drexel, Morgan & Co]] with [[J.P. Morgan|John Pierpont Morgan]] in 1871 as his junior partner, who also founded [[Drexel University]] in 1891.{{sfnp|Rottenberg|2001}} His maternal grandparents were John Roset (1794–1870) and Mary Ann Laning (1807–1880). His paternal grandfather was Austrian-born American banker [[Francis Martin Drexel]] (1792–1863).{{cite news|title=FRANCIS DREXEL'S WILL.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1885/02/23/archives/francis-drexels-will.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=23 February 1885}}{{cite book|last=McDonald|first=Edward D.|author2=Edward M. Hinton|title=Drexel Institute of Technology 1891–1941|publisher=Haddon Craftsmen, Inc.|year=1942|isbn=1-4067-6374-8|pages=4–5}} ==Career== In 1878, Drexel began working for his father's firm, [[Drexel & Company|Drexel & Co.]] in Philadelphia, and was made a partner on January 1, 1890.{{cite book|last1=Rottenberg|first1=Dan|title=The Man who Made Wall Street: Anthony J. Drexel and the Rise of Modern Finance|date=2001|publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania Press]]|isbn=0812236262|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tDDZPuL7svkC&pg=PA186&lpg=PA186&dq=Anthony+Joseph+Drexel+(1864%E2%80%931934)&source=bl&ots=u9aKiH805N&sig=IcTkuwRL6qU-8n6YFPDriYTF3Dc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwidl9Woh8DTAhWKOyYKHZXtD5IQ6AEIVTAO#v=onepage&q=Anthony%20Joseph%20Drexel%20(1864%E2%80%931934)&f=false|accessdate=25 April 2017|language=en}} He was a partner at Drexel until October 21, 1893, when he resigned at age 29 after 16 years of working and just four months after his father's death, from Drexel & Co. of Philadelphia, [[Drexel, Morgan & Co.]] of New York, and [[Drexel, Harjes & Co.]] of Paris.{{cite news|title=WANTS TO ENJOY HIMSELF.; Anthony J. Drexel, Jr., to withdraw from Hoeses His Father Founded.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1893/10/21/archives/wants-to-enjoy-himself-anthony-j-drexel-jr-to-withdraw-from-hoeses.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=21 October 1893}} At the time, a close friend of his exclaimed to ''[[The New York Times]]'', "He does not care to assume the cares and responsibilities which are attached to the business. He is a young man who is very fond of life in the society. His pleasures would have to be curtailed immeasurably were he to continue closely identified with the business his father established, and he does not care for the confinement and close application to which he would be subjected. He prefers to be free footed, and will withdraw. That is all there is to his action. It is said it has no significant whatsoever." Shortly thereafter, he bought one of the most valuable residences in Philadelphia, the Wilstach mansion at the northeast corner of 18th and Walnut Streets, for $175,000.{{cite news|title=PERSONAL GOSSIP.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1893/10/29/archives/personal-gossip.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=29 October 1893}} In November of the same year, he also bought the steamer, ''Avenel'' from W. P. Whitlock.{{cite news|title=Yachting Odds and Ends.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1893/11/17/109733208.html?pageNumber=3|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 17, 1893|language=en}} ===Lifestyle=== After his father's death on June 30, 1893, Drexel decided to live in Europe. He lived in London on [[Grosvenor Square]] and [[Carlton House Terrace]] for several years. While there, they were friends with [[Clyde Fitch]], a successful and prolific dramatist.{{cite book|last1=Dearinger|first1=Kevin Lane|title=Clyde Fitch and the American Theatre: An Olive in the Cocktail|date=July 29, 2016|publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]]|isbn=9781611479485|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GhKvDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA290&lpg=PA290&dq=Anthony+Joseph+Drexel+(1864%E2%80%931934)&source=bl&ots=pdd9OcQ36h&sig=3nviUrK7yet5zPaXBgKEee3TAt8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwidl9Woh8DTAhWKOyYKHZXtD5IQ6AEIXTAQ#v=onepage&q=Anthony%20Joseph%20Drexel%20(1864%E2%80%931934)&f=false|accessdate=25 April 2017|language=en}} From 1915 until his death, however, he resided at the 68 rue de Bellechasse in [[Paris]] as well as homes in the provinces, after his difficult divorce with his wife. In addition to his reputation as a lavish entertainer, he was known as a keen yachtsman and owned several famous yachts including ''Sayonara'' and ''Aloma''. He was a member of the [[Philadelphia Club]], Rabbit Club, [[Racquet Club of Philadelphia|Racquet Club]] and [[Corinthian Yacht Club of Philadelphia|Corinthian Club]] in Philadelphia and the [[Knickerbocker Club]], [[Union Club of the City of New York|Union Club]], [[New York Yacht Club]], and Turf and Field Club of New York. ==Personal life== [[File:Mrs. A.J. Drexel, Lallie Charles, Photo Lallie Charles.jpg|thumb|Photograph of Drexel's wife, Rita Armstrong Drexel, by [[Lallie Charles]]]] On September 14, 1886, he married Margarita "Rita" Armstrong (1867-1948), the daughter of John Armstrong of the Baltimore Armstrongs. Her sister, Annie M. Armstrong, was the mother of [[Anita of Braganza|Princess Miguel of Braganza, Duchess of Viseu]], and her aunts were married to Morton P. Henry and Louis Norris.{{cite news|title=MR. DREXEL'S BRIDE.; THE YOUNG BANKER'S MARRIAGE TO MISS RITA ARMSTRONG.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1886/09/15/archives/mr-drexels-bride-the-young-bankers-marriage-to-miss-rita-armstrong.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 September 1886}} Together, they had: * Anthony Joseph Drexel II (1887–1946),{{cite news|title=A.J. DREXEL DEAD; RETIRED BROKER, 58; Great-Grandson of Founder of Philadelphia Banking House Prominent as Sportsman|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1946/02/26/archives/aj-drexel-dead-retired-broker-58-greatgrandson-of-founder-of.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 February 1946}} who married Marjorie G. Gould (1890–1955), eldest daughter of [[George Jay Gould I]], in 1910.{{cite news|title=MARJORIE GOULD WEDS TO-DAY; Her Marriage to Anthony J. Drexel, Jr., to be Held in St. Bartholomew's Church|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1910/04/19/archives/marjorie-gould-weds-today-her-marriage-to-anthony-j-drexel-jr-to-be.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 April 1910}} * Margaretta Armstrong Drexel (1889-1952),{{cite web|title=Margaretta Armstrong Finch-Hatton (née Drexel), Countess of Winchilsea and Nottingham|url=http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait/mw196611/Margaretta-Armstrong-Finch-Hatton-ne-Drexel-Countess-of-Winchilsea-and-Nottingham?|website=npg.org.uk|publisher=[[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]]|accessdate=25 April 2017}} who married [[Guy Finch-Hatton, 14th Earl of Winchilsea]] (1885-1939),{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special Cable To The New York|title=EARL OF WINCHILSEA, 14TH TO HOLD TITLE; Married A.J. Drexel's Daughter in Brilliant Ceremony in 1910|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1939/02/11/archives/earl-of-winchilsea-14th-to-hold-title-married-aj-drexels-daughter.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 February 1939}} in 1910.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special Cable To The New York|title=MISS DREXEL WEDS VISCOUNT MAIDSTONE; St. Margaret's, Westminster, Thronged at Nuptials of Daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. J. Drexel. 8,000 OUTSIDE THE CHURCH Many Americans Attend Ceremony--Ten Pretty Bridesmaids in Procession--Reception at Drexel Home.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1910/06/09/archives/miss-drexel-weds-viscount-maidstone-st-margarets-westminster.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 June 1910}} * [[John Armstrong Drexel]] (1891-1958), an aviation pioneer.{{cite journal |title=Events of the Month in Aeronautics |journal=Popular Mechanics |volume=14 |date=October 1910 |page=505}}{{cite news|title=DREXEL FLYING FOR FRANCE.; Young Philadelphian in Lafayette Escadrille on West Front.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1917/05/15/archives/drexel-flying-for-france-young-philadelphian-in-lafayette.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 May 1917}} * Louis Clapier Norris Drexel (1896-1962), who married Nancy Doreen Harrington Grayson (1899-1962),{{cite web|last1=Snider|first1=Diane Elsasser|title=Louis Clapier Norris Drexel|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/140719865|website=www.findagrave.com|publisher=Find A Grave Memorial|accessdate=10 August 2016}} daughter of [[Sir Henry Grayson, 1st Baronet]] and Dora Harrington, in 1919.{{cite news|title=Louis Drexel, Formerly Miss Nancy Doreen Grayson, Whose Wedding Has Also Annoyed Her Titled Sister-in-Law|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/80676716/|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The Washington Times]]|date=April 27, 1919}} On May 25, 1917,{{cite news|title=DIVORCES A.J. DREXEL.; Wife of Philadelphia Banker Obtains a Decree in London.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1917/05/26/archives/divorces-aj-drexel-wife-of-philadelphia-banker-obtains-a-decree-in.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 May 1917}} Anthony and Margarita divorced after several years of separation and a bitterly contested trial,{{cite news|title=MRS. DREXEL WINS HER LONDON SUIT; Court Holds That Husband Must Pay Under Terms of the Separation Agreement. HAS AN ENGLISH DOMICILE Husband's Plea That He Is a Resident of France Thrown Out ;- He Is Suing in Paris for Divorce,|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B05E3D61239E333A25754C1A9649D946496D6CF&legacy=true|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=17 December 1915}} and in 1918, she married Lt. Col. [[Brinsley FitzGerald]] (1859-1931).{{cite news|title=MRS. BRINSLEY FITZGERALD|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1948/02/13/85211846.html?pageNumber=21|accessdate=10 August 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 13, 1948}}{{cite news|title=MRS. M.A. DREXEL WEDS BRITISH OFFICER; Divorced Wife of A.J. Drexel, Banker, Marries Lieut. Col. Brinsley Fitzgerald in London.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1918/01/10/archives/mrs-ma-drexel-weds-british-officer-divorced-wife-of-aj-drexel.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 January 1918}} Drexel died of [[uremic poisoning]] in 1934, aged 70, while staying in New York at the Hotel Ambassador.{{cite news|title=ANTHONY J. DREXEL, BANKER, DIES AT 70; Head of Famous Philadelphia Family Succumbs Here After Illness of Eight Months, RESIDED LONG IN ENGLAND Keen Yachtsman and Owner of Celebrated Craft -Had Been Host to Edward VII. i|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1934/12/15/archives/anthony-j-drexel-banker-dies-at-70-head-of-famous-philadelphia.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 December 1934}} ===Descendants=== Through his eldest child, Margaretta, he was the grandfather of [[Christopher Finch-Hatton, 15th Earl of Winchilsea]] (1911–1950), who married Countess Gladys Szechenyi (1913–1978), the daughter of [[László Széchenyi|Count László Széchényi Sárvár-Felsövidék]] and [[Gladys Vanderbilt Széchenyi|Gladys Vanderbilt]], in 1935.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Wireless To The New York|title=Gladys Szechenyi Becomes Bride Of Viscount Maidstone in London; Nobility and Ambassadors of Many Countries Attend Brilliant Church Ceremony -- Both Are Members of Prominent European and American Families.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1935/07/12/archives/gladys-szechenyi-becomes-bride-of-viscount-maidstone-in-london.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=12 July 1935}} Through his oldest son, Anthony, he was the grandfather of Edith Kingdon Drexel (1911-1934), Anthony Joseph Drexel (1912-1948),{{cite news|title=SON TO MRS. A.J. DREXEL, JR.; The Drexels' Second Child -- Their First is Edith Kingdon Drexel.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1912/12/10/archives/son-to-mrs-aj-drexel-jr-the-drexels-second-child-their-first-is.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 December 1912}} Marjorie Gould Drexel (1916-1947).{{cite news|title=Marjorie Drexel to Wed Today.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1935/02/20/archives/marjorie-drexel-to-wed-today.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=20 February 1935}} Through his son Louis, he was the grandfather of Antonia Marguerita Drexel (1926-2007).{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To New York|title=TROTH ANNOUNCED OF ANTONIA DREXEL; Haverford, Pa., Girl Will Be Wed to It. L. W. Earle, Son of Pennsylvania Ex-Governor DEBUTANTE OF THE SEASON Went to Sacred' Heart Convent Fiance's Father Now Aide to Naval Attache in Turkey|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1943/08/28/archives/troth-announced-of-antonia-drexel-haverford-pa-girl-will-be-wed-to.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=28 August 1943}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Rottenberg |first=Dan |title=The Man Who Made Wall Street: Anthony J. Drexel and the Rise of Modern Finance |edition=1st |location=Philadelphia |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |date=2001 |isbn=978-0-8122-3626-2 |oclc=878526769 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Papadakis |first=Constantine |title=Drexel University, a University with a Difference: The Unique Vision of Anthony J. Drexel |publisher=Newcomen Society of the United States |location=New York |date=2001 |ref=harv}} == External links == * {{Find a Grave|14193298|accessdate=April 25, 2017}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060222024745/http://www.library.drexel.edu/archives/history/drexelfamilybibliography.html Bibliography of sources about Drexel family] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Drexel, Anthony Joseph}} [[Category:1864 births]] [[Category:1934 deaths]] [[Category:Drexel family|Anthony Joseph Jr.]] [[Category:19th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:American bankers]] [[Category:Drexel University people]] [[Category:Members of the Philadelphia Club]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Philadelphia]] [[Category:Burials at The Woodlands Cemetery]] [[Category:American people of Austrian descent]]

'''Application retirement''', also called '''application decommissioning'''<ref>[http://www.smaele.nl/documents/IBM-Application%20consolidation-2012.pdf Application consolidation and retirement projects: Strategies that deliver ROI by IBM (Oct 2012)] </ref> and '''application sunsetting''', is the practice of shutting down [[data redundancy|redundant]] or obsolete business applications while retaining access to the historical [[data (computing)|data]]. [[Legacy application]]s are often maintained solely to provide infrequent or sporadic access to data within the application [[database]] for regulatory or business purposes. With some organizations spending upwards of 75% of their [[application software]] budgets on ongoing [[data maintenance|maintenance]],<ref>[http://whitepapers.zdnet.com/abstract.aspx?docid=947913 A Practical Guide for Retiring Applications by Informatica (2009)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718152513/http://whitepapers.zdnet.com/abstract.aspx?docid=947913 |date=July 18, 2011 }}</ref> application retirement can deliver significant cost savings.
The act of application retirement usually involves [[data migration|migrating data]] from the legacy application [[database]] to another [[Software repository|data repository]] or [[archive]] store that can be accessed independently using [[Standardization|industry standard]] reporting or [[business intelligence]] tools. Application retirement allows [[Information technology|IT]] departments within companies to reduce the software, hardware and resources required to manage legacy data.

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry |image = ABPI logo.png |size = 200px |caption = |abbreviation = APBI |formation = 1891 |status = [[Industry trade group]] |purpose = Pharmaceutical industry trade organisation |location = ABPI Head Office, 7th floor, Southside, 105 Victoria Street, London |region_served = UK |membership = Pharmaceutical manufacturers |leader_title = Chief Executive |leader_name = Mike Thompson,{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Stephen Whitehead (CEO, 2011)<ref>[http://www.abpi.org.uk/media-centre/newsreleases/2011/Pages/050411b.aspx Stephen Whitehead appointed new Chief Executive of ABPI] 2011</ref> |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |budget = |website = [http://www.abpi.org.uk ABPI] }}
The '''Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry''' (ABPI) is the [[trade association]] for over 120 companies in the UK producing prescription medicines for humans, founded in 1891. It is the British equivalent of America's [[Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America|PhRMA]], however the member companies research, develop, manufacture and supply 80% of the medicines [[Prescription Only Medicines|prescribed]] through the [[National Health Service]].
==History== The organisation was founded in London in 1891 and originally known as the "Drug Club". A rival institution to represent wholesalers, the "Northern Wholesale Druggists' Association", was formed in 1902 and lasted until 1966.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}
==Management and offices== A board of management of members oversee the ABPI. The Board is made up of individuals who are elected by members to represent the industry and up to five people who are co-opted by the Board. Elections commence every January for elected seats to ensure that the Board is fully representative and has access to the broadest range of skills and expertise possible.
{{As of|2014}}, the Association's research director was Bina Rawal.<ref name=piesing2014>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/aug/23/tech-end-animals-drugs-testing | title=How tech could spell the end of animals in drugs testing | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=August 23, 2014 | author=Piesing, Mark | location=London | deadurl=no<!--present in archive.org-->}}</ref>
ABPI's head office is in London with three regional offices in Cardiff, Belfast and Edinburgh.
==Membership== ABPI membership is not open to individuals, only companies. Members fall into three categories:
* Full members who hold [[marketing authorization]] for, manufacture or supply [[prescription medicine]] for human use and undertake business in the UK * Research affiliate members who carry out business in the UK and are involved in research and/or development of medicines for human use, but do not have a UK sales operation, for example [[Contract Research Organisation]]s (CROs) or [[Contract manufacturing organization]]s * General affiliate members, who operate in the UK, have a business interest in the industry and will typically provide products or services to the industry, although not producing prescription medicines, for example law firms
==Functions== The ABPI represents the views of the pharmaceutical industry to government and decision makers in the UK, i.e. is a [[lobbying organization]].
The organisation has six departments: * Commercial * Communications * Legal * Membership services * [[NHS]] partnerships * Research, medical and innovation
The medical and innovation department oversees complimentary resources for schools in UK to promote links between school science subjects and their applications in industrial research.<ref>[http://www.abpischools.org.uk/ ABPI resources for schools] ABPI, n.d.</ref> The department also runs a careers website.<ref>[http://www.abpicareers.org.uk ABPI Careers in the Pharmaceutical Industry] ABPI, n.d.</ref> The association sponsors booklets on a range of conditions, aimed at patients, carers and healthcare professionals.
The association has lobbied{{when|date=July 2017}} for the UK government to adopt the [[Directive on the patentability of biotechnological inventions|European Union directive on biotechnology research]].{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}
==Code of Practice== The Code of Practice of the ABPI covers the promotion of medicines for prescribing to health professionals and administrative staff as well as the provision of information to the public about prescription only medicines in the UK. All ABPI member companies are obliged to comply with both the spirit and letter of the Code. The Code was first published in 1958 and undergoes revisions at least every two years.<ref>[http://www.pmcpa.org.uk/thecode/InteractiveCode2016/Pages/default.aspx The Code of Practice of the ABPI] 2016 ABPI</ref> It is administered by the Prescription Medicines Code of Practice Authority(PMCPA).<ref>[http://www.pmcpa.org.uk/Pages/default.aspx Prescription Medicines Code of Practice Authority] ABPI, n.d.</ref>
==Criticism== [[Ben Goldacre]] criticised the pharmaceutical industry in his 2012 book ''[[Bad Pharma]]'' as testing itself what it manufactures in "poorly designed trials, on hoplessly small numbers of weird, unrepresentative patients, and analysed using techniques that are flawed by design, in such a way that they exaggerate the benefits of treatments".<ref name=statesman>[http://www.newstatesman.com/sci-tech/sci-tech/2012/10/ben-goldacre-v-association-british-pharmaceutical-industry "Dr Ben Goldacre vs the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry"], The ABPI responds to Ben Goldacre's book Bad Pharma.''New Statesman'', 19 October 2012. accessed 4 July 2017</ref> The ABPI responded that medicines were "tested against the most effective comparator where possible unless there is no current standard of care." Regarding "results that companies don’t like, [which] they are perfectly entitled to hide [..] from doctors and patients . . . academic papers, which everyone thinks of as objective, are often covertly planned and written by people who work directly for the companies, without disclosure." the ABPI responded that it did "... not seek to “hide” trial data" and was recognising there was "still work to be done in ensuring the publication of negative trial data within journals, and in ensuring greater transparency all round within the industry".<ref name=statesman/>
==See also==
* [[Faculty of Pharmaceutical Medicine]] * [[List of pharmaceutical companies]] * [[List of pharmaceutical manufacturers in the United Kingdom]] * [[List of pharmacy organisations in the United Kingdom]] *[[Lobbying in the United Kingdom]] * [[Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency]] * [[Pharmaceutical industry in the United Kingdom]] * [[Royal Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.abpi.org.uk Association for the British Pharmaceutical Industry (ABPI) Website] * [http://www.corporatewatch.org/?lid=397 Profile of ABPI on Corporate Watch Website] * [http://social.eyeforpharma.com/patients/abpi-and-teenage-cancer-trust-ceos-keynote-debate-patient-summit-2012 ABPI and Teenage Cancer Trust CEOs Keynote Debate at Patient Summit 2012] social.eyeforpharma.com
;Video clips * [https://www.youtube.com/user/TheABPI ABPI YouTube channel]

'''Available-to-promise''' ('''ATP''') is a business function that provides a response to customer order enquiries, based on resource availability.<ref>Ball, M.O. et al. (2004), "Available to Promise" in ''Handbook of Quantitative Supply Chain Analysis - Modeling in the E-Business Era'', Kluwer</ref> It generates available quantities of the requested product, and delivery due dates. Therefore, ATP supports order promising and fulfillment, aiming to manage demand and match it to production plans.
Available-to-promise functions are IT-enabled and usually integrated in enterprise management [[software]] packages. However, ATP execution may need to be adjusted for the way a certain company operates.
== Classification == A fundamental distinction between ATP functions is based on the [[push-pull strategy]]. Push-based ATP is based on forecasts regarding future demand - based on anticipation of demand, ATP quantities and availability dates are computed. A prominent example is the traditional determination of ATP based on the [[Master Production Schedule]]. The push-based approach is fundamentally limited by dependence on [[forecasts]], which may prove inaccurate. Gross ATP represents the total available supply, and net ATP represents the supply remaining to support new demands, after existing commitments to customers have been accounted for.
Pull-based models, on the other hand, dynamically allocate resources in response to actual customer orders. This means that pull-based ATP is able to balance forecast-driven resource replenishment with order-triggered resource utilization,<ref>Zhao, Z. (2005), "Optimization-based Available-to-promise with Multi Stage Resource Availability", Annals of Operations Research 135, 65-85</ref> but because resources are allocated with each coming order, the process will yield myopic results.
== ATP Execution == ATP functions can be executed in real time, driven by each individual order, or in batch mode – meaning that at a certain time interval, the system checks availability for orders piled up in that period of time. The process is triggered by the need to check resource availability before making a commitment to deliver an order. For example, ATP calculation using SAP [[software]] depends on the level of "stock, planned receipts (production orders, purchase orders, planned orders and so on), and planned requirements (sales orders, deliveries, reservations, etc.)"
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://help.sap.com/saphelp_scm50/helpdata/en/b2/887941a51a1809e10000000a155106/frameset.htm SAP Library on Product Availability Check using ATP] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080725192049/http://www.oracle.com/applications/planning/ds_global_order.pdf Oracle Data Sheet on Available-to-promise (PDF)] * [http://pic.dhe.ibm.com/infocenter/ssfs/v9r2/index.jsp?topic=%2Fcom.ibm.help.prod.concepts.doc%2Fc_OrderPromisingAndScheduling.html IBM Order Management Order Promising and Scheduling for Sterling v9.2]

revision.text:
{{for|the English singer-songwriter|Ben Goddard (musician)}} '''Ben Goddard''' (1942 - 2018) was a political consultant and founding partner of First Tuesday, Goddard Claussen, Goddard Global, and Goddard Gunster. He is widely regarded as the godfather of [[issue advocacy ads|issue advocacy advertising]] and is credited with creating the genre of national issue advocacy advertising with the [[Harry & Louise]] campaign in the early 1990s.<ref name="washingtonpost">https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A18417-2004Nov28.html</ref>
==Career and accomplishments== He was president of the [[International Association of Political Consultants]],<ref name="iapc">[http://www.iapc.org/officers-board]</ref>{{Failed verification|date=August 2012}} and was a featured columnist in ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' newspaper.<ref>http://www.thehill.com The Hill.</ref> Titled “On Message,” his column reviews and comments on campaign message and strategy.<ref>http://thehill.com/ben-goddard/</ref>
Notable Goddard campaigns include Harry & Louise, the Pacific Life Whales, and Prop 187 in California. According to the Goddard Gunster website,<ref>http://www.goddardgunster.com/ website</ref> Goddard has received dozens of awards for creativity, including a television [[Emmy Award|Emmy]], and his commercials are part of the [[Smithsonian Institution]] permanent collection.<ref name="nytimes.com">https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/30/us/harry-and-louise-and-a-guy-named-ben.html</ref>
In the 1970s and '80s Goddard served as a media consultant to candidates for state and national office including [[Jimmy Carter]], [[Gary Hart]], [[Mo Udall]] and [[Bruce Babbitt]].<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
In addition to his work in the United States, Goddard also created the first political advertising in the [[Soviet Union]] to preserve [[Boris Yeltsin]]'s [[Privatization in Russia|free-market reforms]].<ref name="washingtonpost" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{authority control}}

{{italic title}} '''''Biotech Sweden''''' was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] magazine about and for the Scandinavian life science and biotech industry.
==History and profile== ''Biotech Sweden'' was first published on 9 April 2002 by IDG Sweden, a subsidiary of [[International Data Group|IDG]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Jan Sandred|title=Biotech Sweden – A Business Model Case Study in Innovation Journalism|url=http://innovationjournalism.org/archive/INJO-1-3_split/INJO-1-3_sandred.pdf|work=Innovation Journalism|accessdate=6 May 2015|format=Conference Paper|date=April 2004}}</ref> It was sister publication of ''Bio-IT World''.<ref name=ada/> At its initial phase ''Biotech Sweden'' was published seven times a year.<ref name=ada>{{cite news|title=IDG to publish 'Biotech' magazine in Sweden|url=http://adage.com/article/btob/idg-publish-biotech-magazine-sweden/253684/|accessdate=6 May 2015|work=Ad Age|date=14 February 2002}}</ref> Then it began to be published 11 times per year. The readers were mainly people working in the [[biotechnology]] [[Medical technology|medtech]] and [[Pharmaceutical industry|pharma]] industry of the [[Nordic countries]]. It also carried the largest life science web news service of the Nordic countries, www.lifesciencesweden.se, with four newsletter distributed three times a week, subscription free-of-charge. On the website the magazine provided daily news in Swedish and a weekly news-letter covering life science news of the Nordic countries, plus also access to The Scandinavian Life Science Industry Guide, a database of all life science, medtech and labtech companies of Scandinavia. ''Life Science Sweden'' is also official media partner of Sweden Bio.
The [[editor-in-chief]]s included Ingrid Heath, Jörgen Lindqvist, Ingrid Helander and Loth Hammar.
In 2012, the magazine changed its name to ''Life Science Sweden'' and in 2013 it was sold to Mentor Communications AB.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.lifesciencesweden.se Life Science Sweden]

revision.comment: Revert changes back as Chandler is not a 'Brexiteer' shown by the apology by The Guardian
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Christopher Chandler | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1960{{cite web|author1=Tom Harper|title=Christopher Chandler: Russian spy? Money man for Putin and Trump? No — I’m just a shy billionaire|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/christopher-chandler-spy-money-man-for-putin-and-trump-no-im-just-a-shy-billionaire-2h58mbmqh|website=The Times|accessdate=17 May 2018|date=13 May 2018|quote="1960 Born in Hamilton, New Zealand"}} | birth_place = [[Matangi, New Zealand|Matangi]], [[New Zealand]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Dubai]], United Arab Emirates | nationality = [[New Zealand]] & [[Malta]] | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma mater = [[University of Auckland]] | employer = | occupation = | title = | salary = | networth = US$1.7 billion | known for = Founder of Dubai-based investment company{{cite web|author1=Charles Moore|title=Using Parliamentary privilege to fight the Brexit war is an abuse of power|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/05/11/using-parliamentary-privilege-fight-brexit-war-abuse-power/|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 May 2018|date=11 May 2018|quote="...and “hedge fund” (though Mr Chandler has never owned or run one)"}} [[Legatum]] | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = | children = | parents = Robert Chandler
[[Ana Tzarev]] | relatives = [[Richard Chandler (businessman)|Richard Chandler]] (brother) }} '''Christopher Chandler''' (born 1960) is a New Zealand-born, Maltese [[billionaire]] and founder of Dubai-based [[investment company]] [[Legatum]]. According to ''[[The Guardian]]'', he has a net worth of $1.7 billion.{{cite news|last=Clark|first=Andrew|date= |title=School aims to seed the world with business sense|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/may/22/globaleconomy.internationalaidanddevelopment|location=Boston|access-date=14 October 2017}} ==Early life== Born in [[Matangi, New Zealand|Matangi]], Chandler is the son of [[beekeeper|beekeepers]] Robert and Marija Chandler, who launched and operated Chandler House, a department store in [[Hamilton, New Zealand]].{{cite web |url=http://www.legatum.com/about-us/our-story/ |title=Our story |publisher=Legatum |access-date=14 October 2017}} He attended the [[University of Auckland]], earning a degree in law in 1982.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=16 March 2006 |title=Secrets of Sovereign |url=https://www.institutionalinvestor.com/article/b150nr9k08bfxb/secrets-of-sovereign |publisher=Institutional Investor |access-date=14 October 2017}} In 1982, Christopher and his brother, [[Richard Chandler (businessman)|Richard]], took over the business and expanded it to ten stores, adding fashion design, manufacturing and real estate, before starting to look for international investment opportunities.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/christopher-chandler/ |title=Christopher Chandler |publisher=Forbes |access-date=14 October 2017}} ==Sovereign Capital== In 1986, the brothers formed investment firm Sovereign Global in Monaco to focus on transitioning industries in Russia, Latin America and Eastern Europe. The business operated by investing in assets which it felt were mispriced in times of crisis. One of the company's first major investments was in Hong Kong real estate, a market which investors had fled after the signing of the [[Sino-British_Joint_Declaration|Sino-British Accord]]. The company also invested in the Brazilian telecommunications industry, just after the country came out of hyperinflation, and in Russia, just after the fall of communism. During the [[1997_Asian_financial_crisis|Asian banking crisis]], the brothers made significant investments in both Japan, including taking stakes in UHJ Holdings, Mizuho Financial Group, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp., and Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group. The brothers of took a stake in South Korean refiner SK Corp., where they unsuccessfully tried to "oust" its CEO and Chairman. In 2002, the brothers were the fourth largest investor in [[Gazprom]], the Russian state-controlled gas company.{{cite news |last=Leroux |first=Marcus |date=14 October 2017 |title=Christopher Chandler: billionaire behind Legatum think tank has unrivalled access to Brexit MPs |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/unrivalled-access-of-secretive-billionaire-christopher-chandler-funds-legatum-institute-885pb9vjc |access-date=14 October 2017}} The dog of their representative on the Board, [[Boris Fyodorov]], was poisoned by cyanide, which allegedly may have been the result of their campaign to clean up the company's governance. ==Legatum== In 2006, Christopher founded Dubai-based [[Legatum|Legatum Capital]] after splitting off from his brother. The company was co-founded with Mark Stoleson, Philip Vassiliou and Alan McCormick. Legatum is a private, multibillion-dollar investment firm that puts money into companies in developing countries as well as the world's capital markets. In April 2012, Legatum acquired its own building in the [[Dubai_International_Financial_Centre|Dubai International Finance Centre]]. ==Personal life== Chandler is publicity shy and there exist few photographs of him nor much information about his personal life. He enjoys windsurfing, water-skiing and riding motorcycles. The Chandler brothers bought [[La Fleur du Cap]] in [[Cap Ferrat]] for their parents. It was previously owned by [[David Niven]] and [[Charlie Chaplin]]. Chandler became a citizen of [[Malta]], a member-state of the [[European Union]], in 2016.{{cite news|last1=O'Murchu|first1=Cynthia|title=Malta grants EU citizenship to Legatum backer|url=https://www.ft.com/content/110f57ee-02a3-11e8-9650-9c0ad2d7c5b5?desktop=true|accessdate=January 29, 2018|work=Financial Times|date=January 29, 2017|quote=The New Zealand-born billionaire behind Legatum, the London based think-tank that emerged as one of the most vocal advocates for Britain’s departure from the single market and the customs union, has obtained EU citizenship via Malta.}} [[Roberta Metsola]], a [[Member of the European Parliament]] (MEP) representing [[Malta]], said in January 2018, when the news of his Maltese citizenship became public, that it was "surreal" that a [[Brexit]] backer had applied for an EU passport.[https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20180129/local/major-brexit-supporter-obtains-maltese-passport-ft.669224 Major Brexit supporter obtains Maltese passport - FT], ''[[Times of Malta]]'', January 29, 2018, accessed March 22, 2018. It subsequently became clear that Chandler was not a Brexiter, and his application for Maltese citizenship was made before the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|UK referendum]] in June 2016.[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/28/apology-christopher-chandler], ''[[The Guardian]]'', February 28, 2018, accessed October 25, 2018. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chandler, Christopher}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Waikato]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:Maltese businesspeople]] [[Category:New Zealand billionaires]] [[Category:Maltese billionaires]]

{{Advert|date=September 2017}} {{pp|small=yes}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Clem Chambers | image = chambers-30a.jpg | birth_name = Clement Hadrian Chambers | birth_date = 1963 | birth_place = [[Kent]],
England, United Kingdom | nationality = British | occupation = CEO of [[ADVFN]] CEO of [[Online Blockchain]] | website = www.advfn.com }} '''Clement Hadrian Chambers''' is a British entrepreneur, author, journalist and blogger known as co-founder and boss of [[ADVFN]] (LSE:AFN),[http://www.advfn.com ADVFN] – official website, which spurred a career as a financial commentator. ==Business career== Chambers entered the software industry in the 1980s where he founded computer games developer ([[CRL Group]]), [[MMORG|massively multiplayer game]]s, multimedia and the Internet{{Verify source|date=July 2013}}.{{cite web | url=http://www.crashonline.org.uk/19/crl.htm | title=COMPUTER RENTALS LIMITED: FROM CAVEMEN TO ROCKY HORRORS | publisher=[[Crash (magazine)|Crash]] (via CrashOnline.org.uk) | author=Roger Kean |date=August 1985 | accessdate=13 August 2009}}{{cite web | url=http://www.on-line.co.uk/directors.htm | title=On-line PLC Directors| publisher=On-line PLC | accessdate=13 August 2009}}{{cite web | url=http://www.gatecentral.com/shared_docs/Timeline2.html | title=Gate Central Time Line| publisher=Gate Central | accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://markets.ft.com/research/Markets/Tearsheets/Directors-and-dealings?s=AFN:LSE | title=LSE| publisher=LSE | accessdate=9 November 2011}} In 1989 Chambers co-founded [[On-line PLC]]. The company was amongst the first to develop both massively multiplayer internet games and CD-ROM boxed products.{{cite web | url=http://www.mobygames.com/company/on-line-plc | title=Moby Games| publisher=Moby Games | accessdate=9 November 2011}} In 1999 Chambers co-founded, and became director of, [[Akaei]] PLC, the games development and publishing subsidiary of On-line PLC. In October 2017, the company announced that it intended to put forward a special resolution to change its name from On-line PLC to [http://www.onlineblockchain.io/ Online Blockchain Plc] to reflect its work in the blockchain technology and cryptocurrency fields. He is also non-executive director of Avarae,[http://www.avarae.com/investor-relations-2/board-of-directors/ Board of Directors], Avarae.com a specialist investment company dedicated to investing in rare and high quality coins. ==Media and writing== Clem is often a co-presenter on [[CNBC]], CNBC Arabia and CNBC Europe.{{cite web|title=Clem Chambers - CNBC|url=http://search.cnbc.com/main.do?target=all&keywords=clem%20chambers|work=CNBC|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708170514/http://search.cnbc.com/main.do?target=all&keywords=clem%20chambers|archivedate=8 July 2011|deadurl=y}} He has been a market commentator on [[BBC News (TV channel)|BBC News]], [[Newsnight]], [[BBC One]], [[CNN]], [[Al Jazeera]], [[Sky News]], [[TF1]], [[Working Lunch]], China's [[Phoenix TV]], Canada's [[Business News Network]] and numerous US radio stations.{{cite web | url=http://video.cnbc.com/gallery/?video=3000048070 | title=CNBC| publisher=CNBC | accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2011/09/201192884338329889.html | title=Al Jazeera| publisher=Al Jazeera | accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/1106797805001 | title=Fox Business| publisher=Fox Business | accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://watch.bnn.ca/headline/august-2011/headline-august-10-2011/#clip514581 | title=BNN| publisher=BNN | accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.thewallstreetshuffle.com/monday-august-29-2011-seg-4/ | title=CNN Radio| publisher=CNN Radio | accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/the_daily_politics/8545457.stm | title=BBC2 – The Daily Politics| publisher=BBC | accessdate=9 November 2011 | date=2 March 2010}}{{cite web | url=http://news.stv.tv/uk/210864-special-report-the-stock-the-web-the-ceo-and-his-lawyers/ | title=STV| publisher=STV | accessdate=9 November 2011}} He has appeared on ITV's [[ITV News at Ten|News at Ten]] and Evening News discussing recent failures in the banking system and featured prominently in the [[Money Programme]]'s ''Credit Crash Britain: HBOS — Breaking the Bank'' [http://www.open2.net/creditcrashbritain/hbos_transcript.html] and on the BBC's ''City Uncovered: When Markets Go Mad''.{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b013n4mv | title=BBC| publisher=BBC | accessdate=9 November 2011}} Clem Chambers has written investment columns for [[Wired Magazine]], {{cite web | url=http://classic.cnbc.com/id/29545350 | title=CNBC| publisher=CNBC | accessdate=9 November 2011}} [[The Daily Telegraph]],{{cite news|title=Telegraph articles by Clem Chambers| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/search/?queryText=%22Clem+chambers%22&Search=Search | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=20 October 2015}} [[The Daily Express]] and [[Daily Mail|The Daily Mail]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/article-1285968/INVESTMENT-EXTRA.html|title=INVESTMENT EXTRA: Betting against the herd|work=This is Money|access-date=2018-11-29}}, and currently writes for [[Forbes]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/search/?q=clem%20chambers#394fa1da279f|title=Forbes|last=|first=|date=|website=Forbes|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-29}}, Business Mirror, {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926132142/http://www.businessmirror.com.ph/index.php/en/business/companies/16593-what-about-gold |title=What about gold?|date=26 September 2013 }} Inversionista,{{cite web |url=http://revistainversionista.wordpress.com/2014/02/18/burbuja-digital/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140317112934/http://revistainversionista.wordpress.com/2014/02/18/burbuja-digital/ |archivedate=17 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }} Index Trader, Gulf News{{cite web|date=15 March 2014|last=Clem Chambers|title=So May is coming; what is there to do?|url=http://gulfnews.com/business/markets/so-may-is-coming-what-is-there-to-do-1.1304267|work=Gulf News|publisher= Al Nisr Publishing LLC|accessdate=20 October 2015}} and YTE. He was The Alchemist stock tipster in The Business for over three years and has been published in titles including [[City A.M.]], [[Investors Chronicle]], Traders Magazine, Stocks and Commodities, the [[Channel 4]] website, SFO and [[Accountancy Age]] and has been quoted in many more publications including [[USA Today]]{{cite news|title=| url=http://content.usatoday.com/topics/topic/Clem+Chambers | work=USA Today|subscription=y}} and most of the main UK national newspapers.{{cite web | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/7f276834-e5ae-11e0-8e99- | title=Financial Times| publisher=Financial Times | accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/ftse-100-in-biggest-fall-since-2008-2359020.html | title=The Independent| publisher=The Independent | accessdate=9 November 2011 | location=London | first=Jamie | last=Grierson | date=22 September 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.mailonsunday.co.uk/money/markets/article-2036423/FTSE-CLOSE-Bank-shares-suffer-fresh-fears-eurozone-debt-crisis.html | title=The Mail on Sunday| publisher=The Mail on Sunday | accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/aug/12/short-selling-ban-experts | title=The Guardian| publisher=The Guardian | accessdate=9 November 2011 | location=London | date=12 August 2011}}{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/markets/8692513/FTSE-live-latest-market-report.html | title=The Telegraph| publisher=The Telegraph | accessdate=9 November 2011 | location=London | first=Rachel | last=Cooper | date=10 August 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/latestnews/view/205226/London-shares-recover-after-losses/ | title=Daily Star| publisher=Daily Star | accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/uk/modest-recovery-for-world-markets-16034283.html | title=Belfast Telegraph| publisher=Belfast Telegraph | accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.cityam.com/markets-and-investments/why-england-vs-germany-winner | title=City AM| publisher=City AM| accessdate=9 November 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/217486/Market-Report-Oil-fuelled-FTSE-hits-30-month-high | title= The Daily Express| publisher=The Daily Express | accessdate=9 November 2011}} He also wrote a monthly spread betting column in gambling magazine Inside Edge for over a year.{{cite web| url=http://archive.fisd.net/wfic/2005/speakers.asp| title=WFIC| publisher=WFIC| accessdate=9 November 2011| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120701135750/http://archive.fisd.net/wfic/2005/speakers.asp| archivedate=1 July 2012| df=dmy-all}} Dial Up for Murder, his first book in The Hacker Chronicles{{cite web | url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Dial-Up-Murder-Hacker-Chronicles-ebook/dp/B00PSAYQ16 | title=Amazon| publisher=Amazon}} series, was released in November 2014, with the second book in the series, Log On For Crime,{{cite web | url=https://www.amazon.com/Log-Crime-Hacker-Chronicles-Book/dp/1503179907 | title=Amazon| publisher=Amazon}} being published soon after. In November 2017 Clem published '''''Trading Cryptocurrencies: A Beginner’s Guide - [[Bitcoin]], [[Ethereum]], [[Litecoin]]'''''. His other financial books include the Amazon best-sellers '''101 Ways to Pick Stock Market Winners''',{{cite web | url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/ADVFN-Guide-Market-Winners-ebook/dp/B0062F6LIM/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1320840098&sr=8-5 | title=Amazon| publisher=Amazon | accessdate=9 November 2011}} '''A Beginner's Guide to Value Investing''', '''Be Rich and The Death of Wealth''', all published by [http://www.advfnbooks.com/ ADVFN Books]. He also writes for a number of stock market and share tipping blogs including: [http://newsletters.advfn.com/clemchambers Diary of a Contrarian Investor], [http://newsletters.advfn.com/buildingincomeportfolio/ Building an Income Portfolio] and more recently [http://newsletters.advfn.com/jekyllandhyde/ Jekyll & Hyde Share Tips]. His financially-tinged novels, all published by No Exit Press, are '''''The Armageddon Trade''''' (2009) ({{ISBN|978-1-84243-297-6}}), a financial thriller [http://www.noexit.co.uk No Exit Press], '''''The Twain Maxim'''''{{Cite web|url=http://www.noexit.co.uk/titles.php/itemcode/521%7Cdate=May%202012|title=Our current books in print, organised A-Z by title {{!}} No Exit Press|last=Press|first=No Exit|website=www.noexit.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-11-29}} (2010) ({{ISBN|978-1-84243-341-6}}) another financial thriller [http://www.noexit.co.uk/titles.php/itemcode/529], '''''Kusanagi''''' (2011) {{cite web|title=Current books in print: Kusanagi|url=http://www.noexit.co.uk/titles.php/itemcode/536|work=Oldcastle books|isbn=978-1-84243-3676|accessdate=20 October 2015}}, '''''The First Horseman''''' (2013) ({{ISBN|978-1842436547}}) and '''''The Shrine''''' (2016) [https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B01AWAU8TK/a05b9-21 edition], all starring the same main character, Jim Evans, a "chippy" Cockney City whizzkid who outplays the rich and privileged. Chambers was shortlisted in 2016 and 2017 as ''Columnist of the Year (Business Media)'' in the [[PPA Awards]] for his column in [[E&T Magazine]], The Institution Of Engineering & Technology, and in June 2017 won silver in the Tabbie Awards for his Money and Markets column in the same publication{{cite web|url=http://www.tabpi.org/2017/2017e.htm|title=2017 Tabbie Winners|website=TABPI}}. Clem has a [[Guild]] on the [https://uk.advfn.com/cmn/fbb/thread.php3?id=43514605 ADVFN website] where people can join and interact with him regarding thoughts on the direction of global markets. It includes discussion of global equities, cryptocurrencies, Forex and Commodities. It is a select group with membership of the Guild being 1000 [https://www.plusonecoin.org/ Plus1] coins{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/10/23/plusonecoin-made-a-cryptocurrency-for-upvotes/|title=PlusOneCoin made a cryptocurrency for upvotes|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en-US}}. In November 2018, Chambers won ''Journalist of the Year'' in the Business Market Commentary category in the [https://newsroom.statestreet.com/press-release/corporate/state-street-announces-winners-2018-uk-institutional-press-awards State Street UK Institutional Press Awards]. The awards recognise outstanding performance in institutional financial services reporting in the UK. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chambers, Clem}} [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:British writers]] [[Category:Media industry businesspeople]] [[Category:Video game developers]] [[Category:People from Kent]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British thriller writers]] [[Category:Cryptocurrencies]]

{{Infobox magazine | title = Diversity Woman | logo = | logo_size = | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | publisher = Sheila Robinson | editor_title = | editor = Jackie Krentzman | editor2=Cathy Krizik | editor_title2 = Design Director | staff_writer = | frequency = | total_circulation = 100,000 |circulation_year = 2013 | category = Business, Diversity | company = | firstdate = 2007 | country = United States | based = Burlington, NC | language = English | website = {{URL|diversitywoman.com/}} | issn = }}
'''''Diversity Woman''''' magazine (commonly referred to as ''DW''), founded in 2007,<ref>http://www.pubexec.com/article/sheila-robinson-dedicated-serving-women-business/1</ref> is an American business magazine that features original articles about entrepreneurship, career development, technology, finance, health, and diversity issues as they relate to women in the business world, spotlighting success stories of business women of all races. With a current circulation of approximately 100,000,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediashepherd.com/2014/02/10-questions-with-sheila-robinson-founder-and-publisher-diversity-woman/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304005145/http://www.mediashepherd.com/2014/02/10-questions-with-sheila-robinson-founder-and-publisher-diversity-woman/ |archivedate=2014-03-04 |df= }}</ref> the motto of ''DW'' is “Leadership empowerment for women who mean business.”<ref>http://diversitywoman.com/about/</ref>
==Conferences==
''Diversity Woman'' magazine sponsors yearly conferences, with the 8th annual conference being held in Washington D.C. in October 2013, under the theme “Mentors, Sponsors and Breaking the Glass Ceiling Through Our Allies”.<ref>http://conference2013.diversitywoman.com/</ref> Each conference features an array of speakers, and culminates with the presentation of the Mosaic Woman Awards. Past honorees have included such respected figures as [[Maya Angelou]],<ref>http://www.jacksonadvocateonline.com/?p=858</ref> [[Soledad O’Brien]],<ref>http://article.wn.com/view/2012/07/25/Women_Business_Leaders_Convene_at_2012_Diversity_Womens_Busi/</ref> [[Darla K. Anderson]], and [[Lynn Tilton]].<ref>http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20121218005921/en/Lynn-Tilton-named-2012-Diversity-Woman-Magazine%E2%80%99s#.UxdPkoUjLTw</ref>
==Publisher==
The Publisher of ''DW'', Sheila A. Robinson was named in 2009 as one of the Top 50 Women in Magazine Publishing by ''Publishing Executive'' (featured on the cover of the June issue). Robinson was also the keynote speaker at the 2008 wives luncheon at the [[NFL]] [[Pro Bowl]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.execwomeningov.org/events-and-activities/193 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130903125241/http://www.execwomeningov.org/events-and-activities/193 |archivedate=2013-09-03 |df= }}</ref> and was nominated for The 2011 North Carolina Small Business of The Year.<ref>http://www.napw.com/profile/11337294/Sheila-Robinson/{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Robinson’s first book, ''Lead By Example'' is due out April 1, 2014.<ref>http://diversitywoman.com/about/</ref> Before launching Diversity Woman, Robinson was the publisher of the regional magazine ''North Carolina Career Network Magazine''.<ref>http://www.pubexec.com/article/sheila-robinson-dedicated-serving-women-business/1</ref>
==Executive Editor==
Executive Editor of ''DW'', Jackie Krentzman<ref>http://diversitywoman.epubxp.com/i/91258/7</ref> teaches courses in journalism at Berkley and also produced several documentaries, the first of which, “American Jerusalem,” will air on [[PBS]] in summer 2014.<ref>http://insightberkeley.com/jackie-krentzman/</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://diversitywoman.com/ Diversity Woman Magazine]
==Publisher Interview== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140304005145/http://www.mediashepherd.com/2014/02/10-questions-with-sheila-robinson-founder-and-publisher-diversity-woman/ Media Sheppard - Feb. 21, 2014]

{{Infobox building | name = Downtown Club | image = File:Downtown-athletic-club.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = The Downtown Club, pictured as the tallest red-bricked building in the middle. | highest_prev = | highest_next = | highest_start = | highest_end = | location = 20 West Street, New York, New York 10004 | coordinates = | pushpin_label = Downtown Athletic Club |map_type = Lower Manhattan#New York#USA | floor_count = 39<ref>{{cite web|url=http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=14354 |title=The Downtown Club |publisher=SkyScraperpage.com |date=|accessdate=February 17, 2014}}</ref> | start_date = 1929 | completion_date = 1930 | building_type = Residential | roof = {{Convert|518|ft|m|0|abbr=on}} | top_floor = {{Convert|515|ft|m|0|abbr=on}} | antenna_spire = | floor_area = | elevator_count = | architect = Starrett & Van Vleck {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = NYC | designation1_date = 2000-11-14<ref name=nyc1/> | designation1_number = 319 }} | architectural_style= [[Art Deco]] | owner = | references = }} The '''Downtown Club''', formerly known as the '''Downtown Athletic Club''', was a [[gentlemen's club|private social]] and athletic club in a 45-story building located at 20 [[West Side Highway|West Street]] in the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] of [[Lower Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[United States]]. It is currently in use as a residential building with [[condominium|condominiums]].
==History== The Club was founded in 1926. By 1927, it had purchased this site next to the [[Hudson River]] to construct its own building. It was completed in 1930.
The high cost of land necessitated a tall building, and the relatively small lot size dictated that the different functions and facilities of the club, including [[swimming pool]], [[gym]]nasium, [[miniature golf]] course, [[Squash (sport)#The playing area (Court)|squash]], and [[tennis court]]s, as well as dining rooms and living quarters, be accommodated on separate floors. The Club flirted with bankruptcy in the late 1990s. Discussions were held with local real estate developers to sell off the top hotel floors and for the Club to retain ownership of the lower floors; however, this never came to pass.
===Architecture=== The building was designed in a classic [[Art Deco]] decor. Its [[architects]], [[Starrett & van Vleck]] are also noted for designing several [[New York City]] department stores including [[Lord and Taylor]], [[Bloomingdales]] and [[Saks Fifth Avenue]] shortly before the design of this Club. It has been designated as a landmark in New York, ensuring the building's unique architectural legacy.
===September 11 and subsequent bankruptcy=== The club was less than half a mile south of the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] and closed after the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]]. The club never reopened, and declared bankruptcy in 2002. The 45-story building is now a residential tower named "The Downtown Club" which opened in 2005.
The clubhouse within the building was not physically damaged in the attack on September 11, 2001, but it was located within the "frozen zone" from which the public was excluded for an extended period during the clean-up after the attack. The club's finances could not withstand the financial impact of such a long closure.<ref>{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Sandomir |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/11/02/sports/college-football-home-of-the-heisman-may-have-to-shut-doors.html|title=Home of the Heisman May Have to Shut Doors |date=2 November 2001 |newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref> The members, as well as the managers and employees, some who had been with the club for over 20 years, were devastated at the loss of the club and the employees' livelihood.
===Present day=== The Downtown Club building is registered as a [[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] landmark site.<ref name=nyc1>''[http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/dac.pdf Downtown Athletic Club Designation Report]'', New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, 2000.</ref> It is currently home to condos and a preschool academy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://manhattan.tlechildcare.com |title=The Learning Experience |publisher=Children's Academy |date=|accessdate=March 30, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://downtownclubny.com |title=Residences |publisher=The Downtown Club |date=|accessdate=March 30, 2014}}</ref>
==Heisman Trophy== It was most famous for its annual awarding of the [[Heisman Trophy]] in its building, given every year to the most outstanding [[college football]] player, and named after [[John Heisman]], the club's first athletic director. The Heisman Trophy was relocated temporarily uptown to the [[Yale Club of New York City]]. The ceremony moved to the [[Hilton New York]] for 2004 and has been presented annually at the [[PlayStation Theater]] since 2005.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.downtownclubny.com/}}
