{{Infobox organization | name = Economic History Association | pronounce = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | abbreviation = EHA | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{birth year|1940}} | founder = | founding_location = | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = | headquarters = Department of Economics, [[University of Wisconsin-La Crosse]]<ref name="Officers"/> | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = 1,000<ref name="jstor"/> | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = Executive Director | leader_name = Michael Haupert | leader_title2 = President (2017–2018) | leader_name2 = [[Cormac Ó Gráda]]<ref name="Officers">{{cite web | url=http://eh.net/eha/about/2017-2018-eha-officers-and-board-of-trustees/ | title=2017-2018 EHA Officers and Board of Trustees | publisher=EHA | accessdate=March 22, 2018}}</ref> | leader_title3 = President-Elect | leader_name3 = [[Price Fishback]]<ref name="Officers"/> | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | endowment_year = | staff = | staff_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|eh.net/eha/}} }}
The '''Economic History Association''' ('''EHA''') was founded in 1940 to "encourage and promote teaching, research, and publication on every phase of [[economic history]] and to help preserve and administer materials for research in economic history". It publishes ''[[The Journal of Economic History]]'' with the [[Cambridge University Press]], holds an annual meeting that usually takes place in September, and awards prizes and grants.<ref name="jstor">{{cite web|title=Publisher Description: Economic History Association|url=https://www.jstor.org/publisher/eha|website=[[JSTOR]]|accessdate=27 January 2018}}</ref> It is also the home to the ''EH.Net Encyclopedia of Economic and Business History''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Encyclopedia |url=http://eh.net/encyclopedia-2/ |work=EH.Net Encyclopedia of Economic and Business History |access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref>
== Membership == There are more than 1,000 EHA members worldwide,<ref name="jstor"/> and composed of faculty and graduate students from universities around the world, as well as economists in the private sector and in government.
Michael Haupert of the [[University of Wisconsin-La Crosse]] is the Executive Director, and [[Cormac Ó Gráda]] is the President.<ref>{{cite web|title=About the Economic History Association|url=https://eh.net/eha/about/|website=Economic History Association|accessdate=27 January 2018}}</ref> Previous EHA Presidents include Oxford's [[Robert C. Allen]], Vanderbilt's [[Jeremy Atack]], UC Berkeley's [[Barry Eichengreen]], Yale's [[Naomi Lamoreaux]], as well as [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Economics Nobel Laureates]] [[Robert Fogel]] and [[Douglass North]].
== Prizes and grants == The Economic History Association supports research through [[Arthur H. Cole]] grants-in-aid and awards prizes for publications, dissertations, and teaching, as well as fellowships and grants for students of economic history.
It awards several prizes for publications:<ref name="prizes">{{cite web|title=Prizes|url=http://eh.net/eha/prizes/|website=Economic History Association|accessdate=27 January 2018}}</ref> * Arthur Cole Prize: best article published in ''[[The Journal of Economic History]]'' each year * Alice Hanson Jones prize: for the best book published biennially in [[Economic history of the United States|American economic history]] * Gyorgi Ranki prize: best book published biennially in non-American economic history * Allan Nevins prize: best dissertation on [[Economic history of the United States|American]] or [[Economic history of Canada|Canadian economic history]], awarded on behalf of [[Columbia University Press]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The Allan Nevins Prize in American Economic History|url=http://eh.net/eha/prizes/the-allan-nevins-prize-in-american-economic-history/|website=Economic History Association|accessdate=27 January 2018}}</ref> * Alexander Gerschenkron prize: best dissertation in non-American economic history * Jonathan Hughes Prize: for superior teaching * Engerman-Goldin Prize: biennial prize for contributions to economic history made in the previous five years. It is the EHA's newest award and whose first award will be disbursed in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=Engerman-Goldin Prize|url=http://eh.net/eha/engerman-goldin-prize/|website=Economic History Association|accessdate=27 January 2018}}</ref>
The society also provides grants to support the early stages of dissertation work in economic history and fellowships to support students finishing their dissertations on the topic. Two [[Kenneth Sokoloff]] fellowships are awarded by the EHA each year to students finishing their dissertations in economic history.
== Annual conferences == For many years EHA has partnered with the [[American Economic Association]] to arrange sessions at the annual [[Allied Social Sciences Association|ASSA]] conference.<ref>[http://eh.net/content/call-papers-eha-sessions-2014-assa Call for papers for EHA sessions at 2014 ASSA]</ref>
The 2018 annual EHA meeting will take place in [[Montreal]], [[Canada]], in September 2018; its theme is "‘From Plague, Famine, and War, Save us, O Lord’ Shocks and Disasters in Economic History".<ref>{{cite web|date = 25 October 2017 |title=Economic History Association 2018 Annual Meeting|url=http://eh.net/eha/economic-history-association-2018-annual-meeting/|website=Economic History Association|accessdate=27 January 2018}}</ref>
== References == <references />

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=September 2011}} {{more footnotes|date=September 2011}} }}
'''Enterprise control''' is the ability to combine control, intelligence and [[process management]] to enable business optimization that is inclusive of business and production operations. It combines the strength of both business processes and production operations processes. It is the deliberate act of synchronizing [[business strategy]] with operational execution in real-time to enable closed loop [[business control]] across an enterprise.
==Key elements of enterprise control==
* [[Enterprise resource planning]] (ERP) * [[Supply chain]] * Environment and [[safety system]]s * Assets * People
Interoperating enterprise and industrial [[service-oriented architecture]]s (SOA) provide industrial companies with the potential for problem solutions that cover entire plants and entire industrial enterprises. This enterprise-wide system can be developed using systems and technologies previously installed. The resulting system, consisting of multiple vendor products acquired over many years working as a single system, is what is referred to as an enterprise control system.<ref name=martin>''Automation Made Easy: Everything You Wanted to Know about Automation-and Need to Ask'' Peter G. Martin, Gregory Hale. {{ISBN|978-1936007066}}</ref> The '''enterprise control strategy''' is built around the premise that manufacturing needs an '''enterprise control system''' to integrate business systems and manufacturing in real-time. The concept of the enterprise control system encompasses everything from sensors and people in manufacturing to the ERP system.
{{quote|This logic does make sense since ERP systems have been refined over a number of years and they create tremendous efficiencies in business operations. Certainly I and others see the need for this integrated systems approach in manufacturing. This seems to be an elusive concept except at manufacturing companies that have brilliant and industrious staff who assemble custom systems.|<ref name=lydon>Bill Lydon, Automation.com</ref>}}
An enterprise control system is the [[open architecture]] framework to integrate control systems with the enterprise while adding functions to improve business performance including MES, optimization, workflow, quality management, and asset management.<ref name=lydon/>
==History== A [[distributed control system]] gave way to process automation systems which lead the way for the concept of collaborative automation process systems developed by ARC Advisory Group<ref>ARC Advisory Group</ref>
Later, enterprise control systems became key terminology in the marketplace.
{{quote|...[I]ndustrial automation interoperates with other functions within the enterprise. Trying to keep up with changing technologies, ... is never easy and the industrial automation environment is no exception. Whether you are a student just starting out or are a top-level executive or manager well-versed in one domain, but have limited knowledge of the industrial automation industry, it’s easy to find yourself adrift in this evolving industry.|<ref name=martin/>}}
ANSI/ISA-95, or [[ISA-95]] as it is more commonly referred, is an international standard for developing an automated interface between enterprise and control systems. This standard has been developed for global manufacturers. It was developed to be applied in all industries, and in all sorts of processes, like batch processes, continuous and repetitive processes.
==ISA95 “levels” for enterprise integration== [[Purdue Enterprise Reference Architecture|Purdue Reference Model]], “95” provides a model that end users, integrators and vendors can share in integrating applications at key layers in the enterprise.<ref>Control Global Magazine</ref> *'''Level 0''' — The physical process — Defines the actual physical processes. *'''Level 1''' — Intelligent devices — Sensing and manipulating the physical processes. Process *sensors, analyzers, actuators and related instrumentation. *'''Level 2''' — Control systems — Supervising, monitoring and controlling the physical processes. Real-time controls and software; [[Distributed Control System|DCS]], [[human-machine interface]] (HMI); supervisory and data acquisition ([[SCADA]]) software. *'''Level 3''' — Manufacturing operations systems — Managing production work flow to produce the desired products. Batch management; manufacturing execution/operations management systems (MES/MOMS); laboratory, maintenance and plant performance management systems; data historians and related middleware. Time frame: shifts, hours, minutes, seconds. *'''Level 4''' — [[Business logistics]] systems — Managing the business-related activities of the manufacturing operation. ERP is the primary system; establishes the basic plant production schedule, material use, shipping and inventory levels. Time frame: months, weeks, days, shifts.
==See also== *[[Control system]] *[[IEC 62264]] *[[Manufacturing execution system]] *[[Enterprise manufacturing intelligence]] *[[Workflow]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.isa-95.com ISA-95] *[http://www.arcweb.com/pages/default.aspx ARC Advisory Group] *[http://www.controlglobal.com/articles/2008/ISA95enterpriselevels.html Control Global Magazine] *[http://www.plantengineering.com/index.php?id=1792&cHash=081010&tx_ttnews%5btt_news%5d=26687 Plant Engineering Magazine] *[https://www.awscloudcertified.com/how-can-augmented-reality-ar-benefit-your-business/ How Can Augmented Reality Benefit Business?] *[http://www.isa.org/Template.cfm?Section=Standards2&template=/Ecommerce/ProductDisplay.cfm&ProductID=7958 ISA-95 Manufacturing Enterprise Systems Standards]
[[Category:Business process management]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Use British English|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = {{small|[[The Right Honourable]]}} | name =The Lord Astor of Hever | image = Gavin Astor.jpg | caption = Gavin Astor, 2nd Baron Astor of Hever | birth_date = {{birth date|1918|6|1|df=y}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|1984|6|28|1918|6|1|df=y}} | death_place = near [[Tarland]], [[Aberdeenshire]], [[Scotland]] | death_cause = cancer | resting_place = | education = [[Eton College]]
[[New College, Oxford]] | spouse = [[Irene Astor, Baroness Astor of Hever|Lady Irene Haig]]
(1945–1984; his death) | children = {{plain list| *[[John Astor, 3rd Baron Astor of Hever]] *Bridget Mary Astor *Elizabeth Louise Astor *Sarah Violet Astor *Philip Douglas Paul Astor }} | parents =[[John Jacob Astor, 1st Baron Astor of Hever]]
[[Violet Astor|Violet Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound]] | relatives = See [[Astor family]] }} '''Gavin Astor, 2nd Baron Astor of Hever''' (1 June 1918 – 28 June 1984), was an English soldier, publisher, peer, and member of the [[Astor family]]. ==Biography== Astor was the eldest son of [[John Jacob Astor, 1st Baron Astor of Hever]] (1886–1971), and [[Violet Astor|Lady Violet Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound]] (1889–1965).http://thepeerage.com/p1587.htm#i15867 He had two younger brothers, Hugh (1920–1999) and John (1923–1987). His mother had two children, Mary (1910–2003) and [[George Petty-Fitzmaurice, 8th Marquess of Lansdowne|George]] (1912–1997), from her previous marriage to [[Lord Charles Petty-Fitzmaurice]] (1874–1914). He was educated at [[Eton College]] and [[New College, Oxford]], before joining the [[Life Guards (British Army)|Life Guards]], where he reached the rank of captain. Business positions included the chairmanship of the [[Times Publishing Company]] and life presidency of [[Times Newspapers Ltd]]. He was appointed [[High Sheriff of Sussex]] in 1955.{{London Gazette| issue=40433|page=1609|date=18 March 1955}} He inherited the barony and [[Hever Castle]] in Kent on the death of his father in 1971. In 1955, he founded the Astor of Hever Trust, a charity aimed to collect donations for arts, medicine, religion, education, conservation, youth, and sport.{{cite web|title=Funds for Historic Buildings|url=http://www.ffhb.org.uk/detail.php?CodeID=87|publisher=ffhb.org}} ==Marriage and children== Astor married [[Irene Astor, Baroness Astor of Hever|Lady Irene Haig]] (1919–2001), youngest daughter of [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]] [[Douglas Haig, 1st Earl Haig]] (1861–1928), and Dorothy Maud Vivian (1879–1939), on 4 October 1945. They had five children:[http://www.thepeerage.com/p8060.htm#i80593 The Peerage, entry for 2nd Lord Astor] *[[John Astor, 3rd Baron Astor of Hever|John Jacob "Johnny" Astor VIII, 3rd Baron Astor of Hever]], [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] (16 June 1946) he married, Fiona Diana Harvey on 1 July 1970 and they were divorced in 1990. They have three daughters. He remarried Hon. Elizabeth Mackintosh in 1990. They have two children. *The Honourable Bridget Nancy Astor (16 February 1948) she married Count Arthur Tarnowski in 1980 and they were divorced in 1986. They have two sons. She remarried Geofrey Smith in 1989. They have one daughter: **John ''Sebastian'' Gavin Tarnowski (1981) **Lucian Francis Philip Tarnowski (1984) **Morya Morvenna Irene Smith (1987) *The Honourable Elizabeth Louise Astor (1 March 1951) she married David Herring in 1979 and they were divorced in 1981. She remarried David Ward in 1985. They have two sons: **Oliver Gavin Joseph Ward (1985) **Victoria Mary Ward (1987) *The Honourable Sarah Violet Astor (born 30 September 1953) she married Hon. George Lopes on 22 February 1975. They have three children: **Harry Marcus George Lopes (7 October 1977) he married [[Laura Lopes|Laura Rose Parker Bowles]] on 6 May 2006. They have one daughter and twins boys: ***Eliza Lopes (17 January 2008) ***Gus Lopes (29 December 2009) ***Louis Lopes (29 December 2009) **Lorna Violet Lopes 6 December 1979) she married Ian Lyle on 21 January 2016. **Sabrina Helen Lopes (4 November 1983) *The Honourable Philip Douglas Paul Astor (4 April 1959) Astor died of cancer in 1984 at his home near [[Tarland]], Scotland. He was succeeded in the barony by his eldest son Johnny.{{cite web|title=LORD ASTOR, HEAD OF DYNASTY AND AIDE AT TIMES OF LONDON|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/29/obituaries/lord-astor-head-of-dynasty-and-aide-at-times-of-london.html|publisher=NY Times|accessdate= 29 July 2002}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{s-start}} {{s-hon}} {{succession box | title=[[Lord Lieutenant of Kent]] | before=[[Wykeham Stanley Cornwallis, 2nd Baron Cornwallis|The Lord Cornwallis]] | after=[[Robert Leigh-Pemberton, Baron Kingsdown|The Lord Kingsdown]] | years=1972–1982}} {{s-reg|uk}} {{succession box | before=[[John Jacob Astor, 1st Baron Astor of Hever|John Jacob Astor]] | title=[[Baron Astor of Hever]] | after=[[John Astor, 3rd Baron Astor of Hever|John Jacob Astor]] | years=1971–1984}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Astor of Hever, Gavin Astor, 2nd Baron}} [[Category:Alumni of New College, Oxford]] [[Category:1918 births]] [[Category:English people of American descent]] [[Category:English people of German descent]] [[Category:English people of Irish descent]] [[Category:English people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:British Life Guards officers]] [[Category:1984 deaths]] [[Category:Barons in the Peerage of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Astor family|Gavin]] [[Category:Deputy Lieutenants of Sussex]] [[Category:Lord-Lieutenants of Kent]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Scotland]] [[Category:High Sheriffs of Sussex]] [[Category:Livingston family]] [[Category:People educated at Eton College]]

{{Infobox person | name = Gordon Tang | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | other_names = Yigang Tang | birth_date = | birth_place = China | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = Singapore | nationality = | citizenship = Chinese | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | known for = | home_town = | salary = | networth = US$1.0 billion<ref name="Forbes profile">{{cite web |title=Forbes profile: Gordon Tang |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/gordon-tang/ |website=Forbes |accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | spouse = [[Celine Tang]] | children = 3 | parents = | relatives = | website = }}
'''Gordon Tang''', also known as Yigang Tang,<ref name="bizjournals2017"/> is a Singaporean [[billionaire]] businessman who owns a controlling stake in Singapore-listed property developer [[SingHaiyi]] together with his wife [[Celine Tang]], who is CEO of the company.<ref name="Forbes profile"/>
In 1980s, Tang was a professional windsurfer from [[Shantou]], China.<ref name="bizjournals2017"> {{cite web |URL=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2017/07/28/what-windsur-ng-and-the-real-estate-business-have.html |title=What Windsurfing and the real estate business have in common |accessdate=August 23, 2018}}</ref>
In the early 1990s, Tang and his wife moved to Singapore from [[Guangdong]], China, and the family later became permanent residents.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/companies-markets/singhaiyi-aims-to-build-branding-as-a-singapore-company|title=SingHaiyi aims to build branding as a Singapore company|first=Lynette|last=Khoo|date=|website=businesstimes.com.sg|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref>
The chairman of SingHaiyi is [[Neil Bush]], brother of [[Jeb Bush]] and former US president [[George W. Bush]].<ref name="Forbes profile"/>
Tang is the chairman of American Pacific International Capital, Inc. (APIC). <ref name="bizjournals2017"/>
Tang owns stakes in Singapore listed companies [[Suntec Reit]], [[OKH Global]] and [[OUE Hospitality]].<ref name="Forbes profile"/>
== Personal life == Tang and his wife Celine Tang have three children and live in Singapore.<ref name="Forbes profile"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use British English|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Admiralty law}} The '''Hague Rules''' of 1924 (formally the "International Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules of Law relating to Bills of Lading, and Protocol of Signature")<ref>[http://www.admiraltylawguide.com/conven/haguerules1924.html ''Admiralty Law Guide'']</ref> is an international convention to impose minimum standards upon commercial carriers of goods by sea. Previously, only the common law<ref>''Liver Alkali v Johnson'' (1874) LR 9 Exch 338</ref><ref>[http://www.lawandsea.net/COG/COG_Seaworthiness_3_absolute.html ''Law and Sea'']</ref><ref>[http://www.lawandsea.net/List_of_Cases/G/Glynn_v_Margetson_1893_AC_351.html ''Glynn v Margetson'' (1893); AC 351 (1907) 1 KB 660;]</ref> provided protection to cargo-owners; but the Hague Rules should not be seen as a "consumers' charter" for shippers because the 1924 Convention actually favoured carriers and reduced their obligations to shippers.
The Hague Rules represented the first attempt by the international community to find a workable and uniform way to address the problem of shipowners regularly excluding themselves from all liability for loss or damage to cargo. The objective of the Hague Rules was to establish a minimum mandatory liability of carriers.
Under the Hague Rules the shipper bears the cost of lost/damaged goods if they cannot prove that the vessel was unseaworthy, improperly manned or unable to safely transport and preserve the cargo, i.e. the carrier can avoid liability for risks resulting from human errors provided they exercise due diligence and their vessel is properly manned and seaworthy. These provisions have frequently been the subject of discussion between shipowners and cargo interests on whether they provide an appropriate balance in liability.
The Hague Rules form the basis of national legislation in almost all of the world's major trading nations, and cover nearly all the present international shipping. The Hague Rules have been updated by two protocols, but neither addressed the basic liability provisions, which remain unchanged.<ref>[http://www.bws.dk/conditions/sea-transport/hague-rules.aspx ''Sea Transport Rules'']</ref>
The Hague Rules were slightly amended (beginning in 1931, and further in 1977 and 1982) to become the [[Hague-Visby Rules]]. In addition, the [[United Nations|U.N.]] established a fairer and more modern set of rules, the [[Hamburg Rules]] (effective 1992). Also a more radical and extensive set of rules is the [[Rotterdam Rules]], but as of November 2015, only 3 states have ratified these rules, so they are not yet in force.<ref>The Jackson Parton Miscellany, 2nd ed., 2012</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox person | name = Helen Vivien Beresford, Baroness Decies | image = Lord & Lady Decies.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Helen Vivien Gould | birth_date = {{Birth date|1893|5|2}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1931|2|3|1893|5|2}} | death_place = [[London]] | death_cause = [[Heart attack]] | resting_place = | spouse = {{marriage|[[John Beresford, 5th Baron Decies]]
|February 7, 1911|1931|reason=her death}} | children = | parents = [[George Jay Gould I]]
[[Edith Kingdon]] | relatives = [[Jay Gould]] (grandfather)
[[Kingdon Gould I]] (brother)
[[Jay Gould II]] (brother)
[[Gloria Gould]] (sister) }} '''Helen Vivien Beresford, Baroness Decies''', formerly '''Helen Vivien Gould''' (May 2, 1893 – February 3, 1931) was a [[socialite]] and [[philanthropist]]. She was one of the two [[Jay Gould]] descendants to marry into European aristocracy. ==Early life== Gould was born on May 2, 1893 in the United States. She was the fourth of seven children born to [[George Jay Gould I]] (1864–1923), a railroad executive; and [[Edith Kingdon]] (1864–1921), an actress. Among her siblings were [[Kingdon Gould I]], [[Jay Gould II]], and [[Gloria Gould]]. Her paternal grandparents were [[Jay Gould]], a leading American railroad developer and speculator known as one of the ruthless [[Robber baron (industrialist)|robber barons]] of the [[Gilded Age]], and Helen Day ([[née]] Miller) Gould. ==Personal life== On February 7, 1911, Helen married [[John Graham Hope de la Poer Beresford, 5th Baron Decies|John Graham Hope de la Poer Horsley Beresford]] (1866–1944), the 5th [[Baron Decies]].{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Mr. and Mrs. G.J. Gould May Formally Announce Daughter's Engagement on Jan. 19. |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F05EFD91330E233A25756C1A9649D946196D6CF |quote=The engagement of the season, one interesting abroad as well as in New York, Is that of Miss Vivien Gould, second daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gould, and Lord Decies. While the engagement has not as yet been formally announced by the Gould family, Lord Decies, on the eve of his sailing for England, has admitted to his friends that it is true. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=December 15, 1910 |accessdate=2009-02-02 }} John was the son of William Robert John Beresford, 3rd Baron Decies and Catherine Anne Dent.{{cite book|last1=Montgomery|first1=Maureen E.|title='Gilded Prostitution': Status, Money and Transatlantic Marriages, 1870-1914|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136214950|page=339|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RT_Uc9UWlpMC&pg=PA339&lpg=PA339|accessdate=21 November 2017|language=en}} Together they had the following children: * Eileen Vivien de la Poer Beresford (1912-?) who married Robert Alfred O'Brien * Catherine Moya de la Poer Beresford (1913–1967) who married Patrick Herbert Bellew in 1936. They divorced and she married Max Wilhelm Johannsen in 1946. * Arthur George Marcus Douglas de la Poer Beresford (1915-1992) the 6th [[Baron Decies]] She died in February 1931 of jaundice and a heart attack in London.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Lady Decies Dies at 38 in London. Former Helen Vivien Gould Was Principal in Brilliant International Wedding of 1911. Was Noted As Hostess. Her Entertaining Was a Feature of British Capital. Husband Is Distinguished Irish Peer. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1931/02/03/archives/lady-decies-dies-at-38-in-london-former-helen-vivien-gould-was.html |quote=Lady Decies, the former Helen Vivien Gould, daughter of the late George Jay Gould of New York, died in London this morning. She had been critically ill here for several days. |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=February 3, 1931|accessdate=2007-11-26 }}{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Died |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,741088-2,00.html |quote=Lady Helen Vivien Decies, 39, daughter and heiress of the late George Jay Gould, wife of John Graham Hope de la Poer Beresford, 5th Baron Decies, Boer War veteran; of jaundice and heart attack; in London. |work=[[Time magazine]] |date=February 16, 1931 |accessdate=2009-02-04 }} After her death Lord Decies married [[Elizabeth Wharton Drexel]], the daughter of [[Joseph William Drexel]], on May 25, 1936. He died on 31 January 1944 at age 77.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Lord Decies dies in England at 77. Soldier, Sportsman, Friend of Taxpayer. Married Gould Heiress Here in 1911. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1944/02/02/archives/lord-decies-dies-in-england-at-77-soldier-sportsman-friend-of.html |quote=Married Gould Heiress Here in 1911. |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=February 2, 1944 |accessdate=2007-07-21 }}{{cite book|last1=MacColl|first1=Gail|last2=Wallace|first2=Carol McD|title=To Marry an English Lord: Tales of Wealth and Marriage, Sex and Snobbery|date=2012|publisher=Workman Publishing|isbn=9780761171980|page=334|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rr7MRSed7h8C&pg=PA334|accessdate=21 November 2017|language=en}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{findagrave|67528137}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Decies, Helen Beresford, Baroness}} [[Category:1893 births]] [[Category:1931 deaths]] [[Category:American socialites]] [[Category:Gould family]] [[Category:British baronesses]]

{{Refimprove|date=June 2017}} '''Jacob Bicker''' (1588–1647) was a Dutch nobleman and merchant. Between 1643 and 1647 he was lord of Engelenburg and a director of the Oostzeevaart, handling Dutch trade with the [[Baltic Sea]].<ref>{{nl icon}} [http://www.herenvanholland.nl/eigenaar.cfm?eigenaarnummer=1810 Jacob Bicker in Heren van Holland]</ref>
==Life== Born in Amsterdam, he was a son of [[Gerrit Bicker]] and his wife [[Boelens Loen|Aleyd Andriesdr Boelens]]. He married Christina de Graeff (1609–1679), daughter of [[Jacob Dircksz de Graeff]] and of Aaltje Boelens Loen.
He was a leading member of the [[:Category:Bicker family|Bicker family]], a major trading family involved in the pelt trade with [[Muscovy]] and supplying ships and silver to Spain. Jacob also belonged to the ''Bickerse ligue'', which opposed stadhouder [[Frederick Henry, Prince of Orange]]. Among his other posts, he held that of [[schepen]] of Amsterdam. In 1643 he inherited the castle and estate at Engelenburg near [[Herwijnen]] from his cousin [[Pieter Dircksz Graeff]] the castle and lordship of Engelenburg near [[Herwijnen]]. In 1647 he died in Amsterdam, shortly before the death of his brother [[Andries Bicker]].
Besides lands in [['s-Graveland (Noord-Holland)|'s-Graveland]] and [[Gooilust]], he also owned country houses in [[Baarn]], [[Soest (Nederland)|Soest]], [[Bilthoven]] and [[Hollandsche Rading]] buitenhuizen: '[[Laagte van Pijnenburg|De Eult]]', '[[Pijnenburg (landgoed)|Pijnenburg]]' and [[Kasteel de Hooge Vuursche]] .
==References== <references/>
==Sources== * {{nl icon}} Zandvliet, Kees, De 250 rijksten van de Gouden Eeuw. Kapitaal, macht, familie en levensstijl (2006 Amsterdam; Nieuw Amsterdam Uitgevers), p. 73 * {{nl icon}} [http://www.ms-visucom.de/cgi-bin/ebidat.pl?id=2191 ''Engelenburg'' in de ''Ebidat – Burgendatenbank des Europäischen Burgeninstitutes'']
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bicker (1588-1647), Jacob}} [[Category:17th-century Dutch people]] [[Category:1588 births]] [[Category:1647 deaths]] [[category:Bicker family|Jacob]] [[category:Dutch businesspeople]]

{{small|([[Chartered Financial Analyst]])}} | occupation = [[Business Executive]], [[Lawyer]] & [[Accountant]] | years_active = 2001 — present | nationality = [[Kenya]]n | citizenship = [[Kenya]] | residence = [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] | known_for = [[Business Administration]] | networth = | home_town = [[Nairobi]] | title = [[Managing Director]] & [[CEO]]
[[Centum Investments]] | spouse = '''{{small|Mrs. Mworia}}''' }} '''James Mwirigi Mworia''' is a [[Kenya]]n lawyer, accountant, and business executive. He is the managing director and chief executive officer of [[Centum Investments]],{{cite web|accessdate=13 June 2014| url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/ehed45lik/james-mworia-kenyan-chief-executive-officer-centum-investments/|title=James Mworia, Kenyan, Chief Executive Officer, Centum Investments|publisher=[[Forbes Magazine]]}} the largest publicly traded private capital firm in eastern Africa.{{cite web|accessdate=13 June 2014|url=http://www.kenyanmagazines.com/james-mworia-ceo-centum-investments-the-business-of-investing-management-august-2010/| first=Brenda|last=Otindo|date=August 2010|title=James Mworia, CEO Centum Investments|publisher=Management Magazine via Kenyanmagazines.com}} He has served in that capacity since 2008. ==Background and education== Mworia was born in 1978. He attended Alliance High School, [[Strathmore University]], and the [[University of Nairobi]]. He has a [[Bachelor of Laws]] from Nairobi University. He is also a [[certified public accountant]] and a [[chartered financial analyst]].{{cite web|accessdate=13 June 2014| url=http://www.strathmore.edu/alumni/strathmore-taught-me-excellence-says-ceo/ |title=Strathmore Taught Me Excellence, Says CEO| publisher=[[Strathmore University]]}} ==Work history== In 2001, Mworia began working as a filing clerk at Centum Investments. Despite having a law degree and several other financial and accounting diplomas and certificates, he accepted this entry-level position. He gradually rose through the ranks, and in 2005 he was appointed chief investment officer at Centum Investments. He served in that position until December 2006, when he joined [[TransCentury Investments]] as its head of investments.{{cite web|accessdate=26 June 2015 |author=Reuters| url=http://uk.reuters.com/business/quotes/officerProfile?symbol=ICDC.NR&officerId=1260206|title = Centum Investment Company - Profile of Mworia, James|date=2014|publisher=[[Reuters.com]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.howwemadeitinafrica.com/how-kenyas-james-mworia-rose-from-intern-to-ceo-in-seven-years/ |title=How Kenya’s James Mworia rose from intern to CEO in seven years| accessdate=20 September 2016| first= Dinfin| last= Mulupi | date=19 August 2015 | location=Cape Town| publisher=Howwemadeitinafrica.com}} In 2008, at age 30, he was appointed chief executive officer (CEO) and managing director at Centum.{{cite web|accessdate=13 June 2014| url=http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/business/2014/06/mworia-from-intern-to-ceo-of-fast-growing-centum/|title=Mworia: From Intern to CEO of Fast Growing Centum|first=Margaret|last=Wahito|date=11 June 2014| publisher=Capitalfm.co.ke}} During his first six years as CEO, Centum increased its asset base from KES:6 billion (US$69 million) to approximately KES:30 billion (US$350 million).{{cite web|title=Centum Posts Improved Annual Profit After Tax| url=http://www.ventures-africa.com/2014/06/centum-posts-improved-annual-profit-after-tax/|publisher=Ventures Africa Magazine|date=10 June 2014|first=Mzwandile|last=Jacks|accessdate=13 June 2014}} ==Other responsibilities== He serves as the chairman of the board of directors at [[Sidian Bank]].{{cite web|accessdate=30 September 2016|newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]]| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/James-Mworia-Law-intern-who-rose-to-best-paid-CEO-in-Kenya/539444-3399968-12kt5ixz/index.html | date=30 September 2016 | title=James Mworia: Law intern who rose to best paid CEO in Kenya | first= Brian | last=Ngugi | location=Nairobi}} He also serves as a board member at the [[Nairobi Stock Exchange]] (NSE), effective June 2015.{{cite web|access-date=26 June 2015 |date=25 June 2015 |last=John Gachiri | url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Centum-s-Mworia-takes-Ciano-NSE-board-position-/-/539552/2765366/-/13mm346/-/index.html | title=Centum’s Mworia Takes Ciano NSE Board Position |first=and Simon Ciuri |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |location=Nairobi}} In June 2018, he is expected to leave the board of the NSE, having served his three year term, and having declined to offer himself for re-election.{{cite web|title=Mworia, Mbaru to leave the NSE board of directors |access-date=8 May 2018 |date=8 May 2018 |first=James | last=Ngunjiri |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |location=Nairobi}} In September 2016, he was named the highest paid executive among the five largest corporations in Kenya, with an annual compensation package valued at KES:201.1 million (approx. US$2 million) annually.{{cite web| newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |access-date=20 September 2016 |date=19 September 2016 |title=Centum’s Mworia tops list of Kenya’s best paid executives | url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/Centum-s-Mworia-tops-list-of-Kenya-s-best-paid-executives/539550-3386730-kehj0y/index.html | location=Nairobi | first=Victor | last=Juma}} ==Personal life== According to a 2011 published report, James Mworia is a married father.{{cite web | date=14 September 2011 |accessdate=20 September 2016 | url=http://africanmillionaire.net/2011/09/millionaire-james-mworia-kenyan-ceo-of | title= Millionaire James Mworia, Kenyan CEO of Centum Investments, East Africa's Largest Equity Firm | publisher=Africanmillionaire.net | author=B. Otindo}} ==See also== * [[Nairobi Securities Exchange]] * [[Uganda Securities Exchange]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/tutuschildren/2012/12/2012123151450144123.html Tutu's Children - James Mworia: 'Being World Class'] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mworia James}} [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Nairobi alumni]] [[Category:Kikuyu people]] [[Category:Strathmore University alumni]] [[Category:Kenyan accountants]] [[Category:Kenyan lawyers]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:CFA charterholders]] [[Category:Kenyan business executives]]

[[Image:Culemeyer.jpg|thumb|The Chemnitz Culemeyer in the [[Saxon Railway Museum]] at [[Chemnitz]] - Hilbersdorf]][[Image:H0 model of Culemeyer heavy trailer with Mercedes front wheel drive and Köf II locomotive.png|thumb|Model of a Culemeyer heavy trailer with tractor (Mercedes LPS 332, [[Wiking Modellbau|Wiking]], ca. 1966) and shunter ([[DRG Kleinlokomotive Class II|Köf]] II, [[Märklin]], 2007)]]
'''Johann Culemeyer''' (16 October 1883 - 20 January 1951) was a German [[engineer]].<ref>{{Lexicon der Eisenbahn |page=155}}</ref>
Culemeyer was born in Hanover in 1883 and, in 1936, he became a director of the [[Deutsche Reichsbahn]] and in that capacity was responsible for the construction, procurement and running of road vehicles, railway wagons and heavy transporters.
As early as 1931, he had designed a transportation system which was subsequently named after him, the "Culemeyer heavy [[trailer (vehicle)|trailer]]".<ref>http://www.berth.eu/waggon_de.html as at 31 January 2009</ref> This heavy road trailer enabled the transportation of [[goods wagons]] on the road. These trailers initially had four axles with 16 solid rubber wheels. From 1935, a six-axle, 24-wheel version was also produced.
Under the [[slogan]] ''Die Eisenbahn ins Haus'' ('The Railway to Your Door') goods wagons were brought to factories and other places that did not have their own railway links from the nearest loading station. It was patented on 29 November 1931 under the name ''Fahrbares Anschlussgleis'' ('Rail Link on Wheels') and demonstrated to the public for the first time on 24 April 1931 at the [[Anhalter Bahnhof]] in [[Berlin]].
In the [[Deutsche Bundesbahn]] the trailers were hauled by ''Kaelble'' tractors; the [[Deutsche Reichsbahn (GDR)]] in [[East Germany]] used ''[[Tatra (company)|Tatra]]'' tractors.
Whilst ''Culemeyer'' heavy trailers have been largely superseded on the roads by lorries, in some factories and firms they are still used occasionally.
On 4 November 1976 a private road belonging to the management of the former Reichsbahn authority (''[[VdeR]]'') in [[Berlin-Marienfelde]] ([[Tempelhof]]) was named after Johann Culemeyer. The road is open to public traffic and is a cul-de-sac with several industrial sites along it, including the ''Berliner Werk der Converteam Deutschland'' that in 1984 moved there as the [[AEG|AEG-Stromrichterfabrik]]. In the vicinity, there is also the ''Schwechtenstrasse'', named after the architect of the Anhalter Bahnhof.
Culemeyer died in 1951 in [[Nordholz]], [[Cuxhaven]], in north Germany.

== Sources == [[:de:Johann Culemeyer]]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Culemeyer, Johann}} [[Category:German businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Hanover]] [[Category:1883 births]] [[Category:1951 deaths]] [[Category:German railway mechanical engineers]]

:''This article is about the New York University dean. For the Saint Louis University historian, see [[Thomas F. Madden]].'' '''John Thomas Madden''' A.M., C.P.A., Ph.D. (1882-1949) was an educator and business leader who served as the dean of NYU School of Business, introduced much of the modern procurement process, and served as president of [[Theta Nu Epsilon]] from 1926-1932 [https://web.archive.org/web/20070928041848/http://www.theamericanminerva.com/thetanuepsilon/11HisOff/Officers.html] and [[Beta Alpha Psi]], the finance, accounting and information systems fraternity from 1930-1932.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927035716/http://www.bap.org/annrep99/fmembers.htm]
Dean Madden was born to a New York City family, and was raised in the Protestant church. He was educated at [[Yale]] and [[New York University]] and worked both as an instructor and administrator at the latter while he was engaged in business as an accountant; he was also a member of [[Alpha Kappa Psi]] professional business fraternity.
From 1927-1940, Madden was dean of New York University's business school, serving as a professor through the thirties until 1947, while rendering procurement training to the military in World War II. Dean Madden started an early form of inmate education using his faculty at Sing Sing. Dean Madden is quoted as saying "This idea is a mighty fine one, especially at this time. There are many men here who would not have been here five years ago. They committed no strange offenses. They merely carried on the business practices they had been used to. But these practices, with the advent of Depression, became criminal."[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,746994,00.html]
In 1929, Dean Madden became the third President of [[Alexander Hamilton Institute]], a highly successful distance education business course started by his fellow [[New York University]] (NYU) instructor and predecessor as dean.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,738018,00.html]
Dean Madden was also the major figure in developing the modern, professional procurement process. He stated in his text, "Budgetary Control" (1930) that it has "became apparent that, due to the amount of dollars at stake, purchases are more effectively handled by an individual who could concentrate on the business of procurement. In transforming requests into materials for their organizations, procurement professionals also have to perform market analysis and do [[product forecasting]] as well as understand the law of contracts."
Dean Madden authored numerous texts of accounting, currency, mortgage banking and other business practices [http://www.antronics.com/cgi-bin/books/amazon.cgi?mode=books&page_num=7&search_type=AuthorSearch&input_string=John+Madden&templates=1&locale=us] ; accounting historian Julia Grant names him as one of the "fathers of modern accounting". [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0815322380]
The educator and business leader was president of [[Theta Nu Epsilon]] from 1926-1932, and again (of the splintered TNE) from 1935 to 1946 and was active in [[the Andiron Club]]. The previous presidents of Theta Nu Epsilon were Joseph James Hartigan and Clarence J. Hand, students of Mr. Madden's at [[New York University]] (NYU).[https://web.archive.org/web/20110728104158/http://thetanuepsilon.org/11HisOff/Officers.html]
The John T. Madden Memorial Award at NYU's [[Stern School of Business]] are named in his honor and in recognition of his achievements.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Madden, John Thomas}} [[Category:1882 births]] [[Category:1948 deaths]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:New York University faculty]] [[Category:American accountants]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2014}} '''Josue Carrion''' (born {{circa|1978}}) is a Puerto Rican businessman. He was also the show host of the television show, ''[[El Tiempo Es Oro (television show)|El Tiempo Es Oro]]''. On December 19, 2014, that show was cancelled by Puerto Rican television channel, [[WAPA America]].<ref>http://www.primerahora.com/entretenimiento/tv/nota/mrcashyeltiempoesorosedespidendewapacontremendafiesta-1054542/</ref>On [[November 16]], 2015, Carrion returned to television in the United States and Puerto Rico, as host of [[Mega-TV]]'s show, "[[Sales de Oro]]".<ref>http://www.elnuevodia.com/entretenimiento/tv/nota/salesdeoroconjosuecarrioncumplesucometido-2127559/</ref>
==Biography== During 2014, Carrion became involved in a dispute with [[Sunshine Logroño]], a well known Puerto Rican comedian and actor who imitated Carrion on one of his television shows.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.metro.pr/entretener/tiraera-entre-mr-cash-y-sunshine/pGXnan!B25EsDc2xIcQ/ |language=Spanish |title=Tiraera entre Mr. Cash y Sunshine |date=January 14, 2014}}</ref>
Carrion lives in [[El Condado]], [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.primerahora.com/estilos-de-vida/hogar-decoracion/nota/asivivemrcash-video-955716/ |language=Spanish |title=Así vive "Mr. Cash" – Vídeo |date=September 21, 2013}}</ref>
==Arrest== On May 28, 2014, Josue Carrion was arrested by the [[FBI]] at [[Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport]] in San Juan after trying to board a flight to New York City. He was accused of trying to bring a loaded weapon on board a commercial aircraft.WAPA-TV announced that his program would go on, but that Carrion would be substituted by two, possibly three, co-workers as show host of ''El Tiempo es Oro''.<ref>http://www.primerahora.com/entretenimiento/musica/nota/eltiemposeradeellos-1012829/</ref> However, after the announcement, Carrion met with Joe Ramos, WAPA-TV's president, and they agreed that Carrion would only take a week off and return to the show on June 9, 2014.<ref>http://elvocero.com/mr-cash-se-queda-en-el-tiempo-es-oro/</ref>
On October 22, 2014, Carrion was declared not guilty of all charges.<ref>http://www.primerahora.com/noticias/policia-tribunales/nota/podriahaberhoyveredictoenelcasodemrcash-1043188/</ref>
==Personal== Carrion has a sister, Jeanie Carrion, who was once a television model on several shows, such as [[Joaquín Monserrat]]'s ''Contra el Reloj'', [[Héctor Marcano]]'s ''Que Suerte'' (both Josue and Jeanie participated in this show), [[Daniela Droz]]'s ''Es Ahora que Eh'' and [[Raymond Arrieta|Raymond]] and [[Dagmar (Puerto Rico entertainer)|Dagmar]]'s show ''Dia a Dia''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.primerahora.com/estilos-de-vida/cultura/nota/jeaniecarrionlanenadepachecocreciovideo-923583/ |language=Spanish |title=Jeanie Carrión: la nena de Pacheco creció-VÍDEO |date=May 24, 2013}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of Puerto Ricans]]

The [[editor-in-chief]] is Donald R. Bacon ([[University of Denver|Boise State University]]). It was established in 1979 and is currently published by [[SAGE Publications]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Use British English|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Keith Cochrane | image = | caption = | birth_name = Keith Robertson Cochrane | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|02|11|df=yes}} | birth_place = Edinburgh, Scotland | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = Perthshire | nationality = Scottish | education = | alma_mater = [[Glasgow University]] | occupation = Businessman | years_active = 1986–present | salary = £1,621,645 | title = Interim Chief Executive, [[Carillion|Carillion plc]] | term = 2017–2018 | predecessor = [[Richard Howson]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/fury-fatcat-carillion-boss-trousers-11855183|title=Fury at fatcat Carillion boss trousering £660,000 AFTER he quit - as 20,000 jobs hang in balance|publisher=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=15 January 2018|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref> | successor = | spouse = | children = 2 }}
'''Keith Robertson Cochrane''' [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] [[Royal Society of Edinburgh|FRSE]] (born 11 February 1965) is a Scottish businessman, former chief executive of [[Weir Group]], [[Stagecoach Group]] and [[Carillion|Carillion plc]] (interim).
==Early life== Born in [[Edinburgh]], Cochrane was educated at [[Dunblane]] High School, Perthshire, and studied accountancy at [[Glasgow University]].<ref>"Cochrane, Keith Robertson, (born 11 Feb. 1965), Chief Executive, Weir Group PLC, 2009–16 (Group Finance Director, 2006–09)." WHO'S WHO & WHO WAS WHO</ref> He qualified as a [[chartered accountant]] with [[Arthur Andersen]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.rsno.org.uk/about/board/?director=Keith+Cochrane&action=Profile |title=Keith Cochrane - Honorary Treasurer |publisher=Royal Scottish National Orchestra |date= |accessdate=10 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222025914/http://www.rsno.org.uk/about/board/?director=Keith+Cochrane&action=Profile |archivedate=22 February 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==Career== Cochrane was Group Finance Director of [[Stagecoach Group]] plc from 1996, becoming Group Chief Executive in 2000. He then joined [[ScottishPower]] plc in 2003 as Director of Group Financial Reporting, and from 2005 was Group Director of Finance.<ref name="businessweek1">{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=428375&ticker=WEIR:LN&previousCapId=416620&previousTitle=UBS%20AG-REG| title=Keith Robertson Cochrane : Executive proflie and biography |publisher=Bloomberg BusinessWeek|date= |accessdate=10 November 2012}}</ref> Cochrane became Honorary Treasurer of the [[Royal Scottish National Orchestra]] in September 2008.<ref name="businessweek1"/>
On 2 November 2009 Cochrane became Group Chief Executive of [[Weir Group]] plc, having joined Weir as Group Finance Director in July 2006. He resigned as a director of Weir Group on 30 September 2016.<ref name="Cochrane">{{cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/krm0AUimqKgzdp2qRmHczhQBKFw/appointments |title=Keith Robertson Cochrane|publisher=[[Companies House]]|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref> Cochrane said that he was "looking for the next opportunity" and that the Weir Group had become "a bit samey".<ref name="Herald">{{cite news|title=Keith Cochrane handed £770,000 to walk from Weir|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/business_hq/company_news/15153650.Keith_Cochrane_handed___770_000_to_walk_from_Weir/|accessdate=16 January 2018|publisher=[[The Herald (Glasgow)]]|date=14 March 2017}}</ref>
In 2015, Cochrane was appointed as the lead "non-executive director” for the Scotland Office and Office of the Advocate General.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/15886349.Revealed__Carillion_boss_helps_Mundell_run_the_Scotland_Office/|title=David Mundell urged to drop Carillion interim chief executive as Scotland Office adviser|publisher=The Herald|date=21 January 2018}}</ref>
Cochrane was appointed to the board of [[Carillion]] plc on 2 July 2015 and on 10 July 2017 he became its Interim Chief Executive.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2017/07/10/carillions-new-boss-promises-aggressive-plan-get-back-track/|title=Carillion's new boss promises 'aggressive' plan to get back on track|publisher=The Telegraph|date=10 July 2017|accessdate=19 August 2017}}</ref> He remained in this position until the company went into [[Liquidation|voluntary liquidation]] on 15 January 2018.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|title=Carillion to go into liquidation|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-42687032#|accessdate=16 January 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=15 January 2018}}</ref> In the final report of the Parliamentary inquiry into the collapse of Carillion, published on 16 May 2018, the Carillion board was described as "either negligently ignorant of the rotten culture at Carillion or complicit in it."<ref name="Carillion report">{{cite book|title=Carillion: Second Joint report from the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy and Work and Pensions Committees of Session 2017–19|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201719/cmselect/cmworpen/769/769.pdf|date=2018|publisher=House of Commons|location=London|page=88|accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> The report continued: :"Keith Cochrane was an inside appointment as interim Chief Executive, having served as a non-executive on the board that exhibited little challenge or insight. He was unable to convince investors of his ability to lead and rebuild the company. ... Non-executives are there to scrutinise executive management. They have a particularly vital role in challenging risk management and strategy and should act as a bulwark against reckless executives. Carillion’s NEDs were, however, unable to provide any remotely convincing evidence of their effective impact."<ref name="Carillion report"/>
The report also recommended that the [[Insolvency Service]] should consider whether the former Carillion directors, including Cochrane, could be disqualified from acting as a director.<ref name="Carillion report recommendation">{{cite book|title=Carillion: Second Joint report from the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy and Work and Pensions Committees of Session 2017–19|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201719/cmselect/cmworpen/769/769.pdf|date=2018|publisher=House of Commons|location=London|page=93|accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref>
In September 2017, Cochrane was appointed non-executive chairman of [[Hydraulic fracturing|fracking]] company [[Third Energy Onshore]].<ref name="Duke-3Sep2017">{{cite news|last1=Duke|first1=Simon|title=City veterans Keith Cochrane and Lord Gadhia go fracking in Yorkshire|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/third-energy-city-veterans-keith-cochrane-and-lord-gadhia-go-fracking-in-yorkshire-dwz6dd6zj|accessdate=10 February 2018|work=Times|date=3 September 2017}}</ref><ref name="Helm-10Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Helm|first1=Toby|title=Carillion links put fracking firm’s scheme in doubt|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/10/carillion-links-north-yorkshire-fracking-third-energy|accessdate=10 February 2018|work=Guardian|date=10 February 2018}}</ref> He resigned as a director in September 2018.<ref name="Hayhurst-18Sep2018">{{cite news |last1=Hayhurst |first1=Ruth |title=“City heavyweights” resign from fracking firm, Third Energy |url=https://drillordrop.com/2018/09/18/city-heavyweights-resign-from-fracking-firm-third-energy/ |accessdate=19 September 2018 |work=Drill or Drop |date=18 September 2018}}</ref>
On 4 January 2018 Cochrane was appointed as Chairman of the Advisory Board of Schenck Process, LLC.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.schenckprocess.com/us/press-releases/Blackstone-Completes-Acquisition-of-Schenck-Process/ |title=Blackstone Completes Acquisition of Schenck Process Appoints New Chairman|date=4 January 2018|access-date=20 January 2018}}</ref>
In October 2018, Cochrane was appointed chairman of Peterhead-based engineer, Score Group.<ref name="Findlay-8Oct2018">{{cite news |last1=Findlay |first1=Keith |title=Executive of bankrupt giant lands new top job |url=https://www.pressandjournal.co.uk/fp/business/north-of-scotland/1579851/executive-of-bankrupt-giant-lands-new-top-job/ |accessdate=8 October 2018 |work=Press & Journal |date=6 October 2018}}</ref>
==Honours== In March 2016, Cochrane was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]], Scotland's National Academy for science and letters.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/1200_2016ElectedFellows.html |title=The Royal Society of Edinburgh | 2016 Elected Fellows |website=Royalsoced.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-03-08}}</ref>
Cochrane was appointed [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the 2016 Birthday Honours for services to business in Scotland.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=61608|supp=y|page=B8|date=11 June 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== Cochrane lives in Perthshire with his wife and two children. His interests include golf, gardening and watching [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland play rugby]].<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox person | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Martha B. Farish | birth_date = October 20, 1918 | birth_place = [[Houston, Texas]],
[[United States]] | death_date = September 17, 2007 | death_place = [[New York, New York]]
United States | death_cause = | resting_place = | residence = | occupation = | known_for = Owner of [[Forego]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | education = [[The Masters School]] | alma_mater = [[Vassar College]] | spouse = [[Edward Harriman Gerry]] | children = Libby F., Cornelia G., Martha G., William F. | parents = [[William Stamps Farish II]]
Libbie Randon Rice | relations = [[William Stamps Farish III|William Farish III]] (nephew) | boards = [[New York Racing Association]]
[[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame]] | honors = {{plainlist| * Thoroughbred Club of America's Honored Guest (1978) * [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame#Exemplars of Racing|Exemplar of Racing]] (2007) }}}} '''Martha B. Farish Gerry''' (October 20, 1918 – September 17, 2007) was an [[United States|American]] [[Thoroughbred]] [[Horse racing|racehorse]] owner named an [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame#Exemplars of Racing|Exemplar of Racing]] by the [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame]].{{cite news|title=Gerry owner of Forego dies at 88.|url=http://thoroughbredtimes.com/national-news/2007/September/18/Gerry-owner-of-Forego-dies-at-88.aspx/|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=Thoroughbred Times|date=18 September 2007|language=en}} ==Early life== Martha B. Farish was born on October 20, 1918 in [[Houston, Texas]]. She was the daughter of Libbie Randon Rice and her husband, [[William Stamps Farish II]] (1881–1942), president of [[Standard Oil]] from 1937 to 1942.[http://www.houstonhistory.com/citizens/whoswho/business/history25hof.htm 174 Years of Historic Houston: Who's Who - William Stamps Farish] She was raised in New York where she studied at [[The Masters School]] in [[Dobbs Ferry, New York]] and [[Vassar College]] in [[Poughkeepsie (town), New York|Poughkeepsie]]. She was the aunt of [[William Stamps Farish III]], the [[United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom]] under President [[George W. Bush]]. ==Career== Gerry was best known as the owner and breeder of three-time [[American Horse of the Year]], [[Forego]] whom she raced under the Lazy F. Ranch banner.{{cite web|title=Forego: Making Them Forget About Secretariat|url=https://www.thecrimson.com/article/1976/4/13/forego-making-them-forget-about-secretariat/|website=www.thecrimson.com|publisher=[[The Harvard Crimson]]|accessdate=27 February 2017|language=en|date=April 13, 1976}} In 57 starts, Forego had 34 wins, 9 seconds and 7 thirds and registered 24 stakes victories including 14 Grade 1 wins. His lifetime earnings amounted to $1,938,957.{{cite web|title=Forego (KY)|url=http://www.equibase.com/profiles/Results.cfm?type=Horse&refno=170261®istry=T&rbt=TB|website=www.equibase.com|publisher=Equibase|accessdate=27 February 2017|language=en}} She was a member of [[The Jockey Club]], a long-time trustee of the [[New York Racing Association]] and of the [[Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association]]. In 1974, she was the recipient of the New York Turf Writers Association award as the woman who did the most for racing and was the [[Thoroughbred Club of America|Thoroughbred Club of America's]] Honored Guest of 1978. In 1983, Gerry, [[Allaire du Pont]], and [[Penny Chenery]] became the first women to be admitted as members of [[The Jockey Club]].{{cite news|last1=Associated Press|title=Martha Gerry, 88, Noted Horse Owner, Is Dead|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/20/sports/othersports/20gerry.html|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=20 September 2007}} ==Personal life== In 1939, she married [[Edward Harriman Gerry]] (1914–2003) at [[St. James' Episcopal Church (New York City)|St. James Episcopal Church]] on [[Madison Avenue]] and [[71st Street (Manhattan)|Seventy-first street]] in New York City.{{cite news|title=Miss Martha Farish Married in Ceremony At St. James to Edward Harriman Gerry; Mrs. William S. Farish Jr., Sister-in-Law, Serves as Matron of Honor--Eight Others Attend Her|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1939/04/23/archives/miss-martha-farish-married-in-ceremony-at-st-james-to-edward.html|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=23 April 1939}} Gerry was the son of [[Robert L. Gerry, Sr.|Robert Livingston Gerry, Sr.]] (1877–1957) and Cornelia Averell Harriman (1884-1966), the daughter of railroad executive [[E. H. Harriman]] and his wife [[Mary Williamson Averell]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1908/03/04/archives/miss-harriman-bride-of-robert-l-gerry-grace-church-so-crowded-by.html New York Times article dated March 4, 1908] Robert was also the nephew of [[Peter G. Gerry]] and [[Edith Stuyvesant Vanderbilt]], and the grandson of [[Elbridge Thomas Gerry]], himself the grandson of [[Elbridge Gerry]], the [[List of Vice Presidents of the United States|5th]] [[U.S. Vice President]].{{cite news|last1=Staff|title=Peter G. Gerry, Ex-Senator, Dies Hours Before His Brother Robert Rhode Island Democrat, 78, Was a Foe of New Deal— Supported Strong Navy|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1957/11/01/90846377.html?pageNumber=26|accessdate=7 April 2016|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=November 1, 1957}} The Gerry's maintained residences in [[Monticello, Florida]] and [[Mill Neck, New York]]. Together, they were the parents of:{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Stephen|date=September 20, 2007|title=Martha Gerry, 88, Bred Forego, Great Gelding of the '70s - The New York Sun|url=http://www.nysun.com/obituaries/martha-gerry-88-bred-forego-great-gelding-of/63067/|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=[[New York Sun]]}} * Libby Farish Gerry{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Mrs. Coxe's Duo Takes Play-Off For Mother-Daughter Golf Title|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E06E4DA123DE333A25755C0A9619C946191D6CF&legacy=true|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=6 July 1960}} * Cornelia Harriman Gerry, who married Richard A. Corbett in 1970.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Cornelia Harriman Gerry Bride|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1970/05/10/archives/cornelia-harriman-gerry-bride.html|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 May 1970}} * Martha Rice Gerry, who married Frank Bradford Townley in 1978.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Martha Rice Gerry Is Bride|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/07/09/archives/martha-rice-gerry-is-bride.html?_r=0|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 July 1978}} * William Farish Gerry (b. 1955), who married Gay Caroline Vincent, daughter of [[Betsy von Furstenberg]] in 1988.{{cite news|title=Miss Vincent to Wed William F. Gerry|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/05/15/style/miss-vincent-to-wed-william-f-gerry.html|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 May 1988}}{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/legit/people-news/betsy-von-furstenberg-actress-dead-dies-1201485244/ |title=Betsy von Furstenberg, Actress and Aristocrat, Dies at 83 |publisher=''Variety'' |date=April 30, 2015 |accessdate=April 30, 2015 }}{{cite news|title=Gay Caroline Vincent, Painter, Is Wed To William Farish Gerry, Stockbroker|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/09/18/style/gay-caroline-vincent-painter-is-wed-to-william-farish-gerry-stockbroker.html|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=18 September 1988}} Gerry died September 17, 2007 following heart surgery at [[New York Presbyterian Hospital]], of which she had been a Life Trustee.{{cite news|title=Paid Notice: Deaths GERRY, MARTHA FARISH|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B04E5DF163AF933A1575AC0A9619C8B63|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=20 September 2007}} Her husband predeceased her on January 24, 2003.{{cite news|title=Paid Notice: Deaths GERRY, EDWARD HARRIMAN|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/01/26/classified/paid-notice-deaths-gerry-edward-harriman.html|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 January 2003}} ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|30em}} ;Sources * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100114081906/http://ntra.com/stats_bios.aspx?id=3506 Martha F. Gerry at the NTRA] {{DEFAULTSORT:Gerry, Marth F.}} [[Category:1918 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Vassar College alumni]] [[Category:American racehorse owners and breeders]] [[Category:People from Houston]] [[Category:New York (state) Republicans]] [[Category:People from Monticello, Florida]] [[Category:Gerry family]] [[Category:The Masters School people]]

page.title: Maternity leave and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

revision.text:
Forty-one countries have some form of paid [[parental leave]], and the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] provides data from these countries about leave length, average pay rate and full-rate equivalent.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/els/family/database.htm|title=OECD Family Database - OECD|website=www.oecd.org|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> Not all countries provide mothers with a pay rate equal to what they would have received if the absence had not occurred.
Rate of basic pay can be defined as fixed pay received through [[minimum wage law]] or an administratively-determined wage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opm.gov/faqs/QA.aspx?fid=e64d74ab-20a3-484c-8682-d2a2b46c22da&pid=adb00212-6ce3-4642-8e6f-95ab709f0d8a|title=What is the definition of rate of basic pay for the purpose of paying a... - OPM.gov|website=U.S. Office of Personnel Management|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> Organizations and activists are working to inform, persuade and change pay-rate laws. Women in the workforce are at a disadvantage; regardless of legislation, a global [[gender pay gap]] is still visible.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Blau |first=Francine D. |last2=Kahn |first2=Lawrence M. |year=2003 |title=Understanding International Differences in the Gender Pay Gap |journal=Journal of Labor Economics |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=106–144 |doi=10.1086/344125 }}</ref> The OECD is a primary supplier of research and data pertaining to parental-leave rights.<ref name=":0" />
== Background == Paid maternity leave is important for women to take time away from work to bond with a child without financial pressures. Of the 193 [[United Nations]] countries, only a handful do not have a paid-parental-leave policy: [[New Guinea]], [[Suriname]], the [[United States]] and a few South [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] [[Island country|island nation]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/10/06/495839588/countries-around-the-world-beat-the-u-s-on-paid-parental-leave|title=Countries Around The World Beat The U.S. On Paid Parental Leave|publisher=}}</ref> The international history dates back to the 1970s, with countries such as Iraq granting full pay for women. By the 1980s, [[Great Britain]] was at the point of giving women benefits but did not specify a pay rate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/features/the-timeline-maternity-leave-2113236.html|title=The Timeline: Maternity leave|date=2010-10-22|newspaper=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-14}}</ref> The history of pay rates is limited and not well-recorded, except by the OECD.
== {{anchor|Different Kinds of Leave}}Types of leave == Maternity leave varies by country, with most developed countries having at least one set type of maternity leave. Most maternity leaves include a length of time to take off, with some form of pay. The following countries grouped by pay rate.
=== United Kingdom === In the [[United Kingdom]] maternity-leave pay is known as Statutory Maternity Pay (SMP), which can cover up to 39 weeks of maternity leave. A woman can expect to earn 90 percent of her weekly earnings for the first six weeks of maternity leave; after that, the rate decreases.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/maternity-pay-leave/pay|title=Maternity pay and leave - GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref>
=== Australia, Canada, and New Zealand === In Australia, women can receive up to 18 weeks minimum-wage from the government; if an employer offers paid leave, a mother can receive that as well. In Canada, a woman can receive 17 weeks of maternity leave: two weeks before giving birth and 15 weeks afterwards. The two weeks before birth are unpaid.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.oecd.org/els/family/PF2_5_Trends_in_leave_entitlements_around_childbirth_Annex.pdf|title=Annex: Detail of Change in Parental by Country|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-12-07}}</ref> In New Zealand, primary leave is 18 weeks of paid leave; special leave covers 10 days (spread out) for appointments or unpaid illness.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.employment.govt.nz/leave-and-holidays/parental-leave/types-of-parental-leave/|title=Types of parental leave » Employment|website=www.employment.govt.nz|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref>
=== Denmark, Greece, and Switzerland === In Denmark, a woman can receive 35 or 46 weeks of paid leave; the 35-week pay leave may be spread over 46 weeks.<ref name=":1" /> Women in Greece must be insured to receive maternity benefits, which include 56 days before giving birth and 63 days afterwards. To receive the benefits a woman must stop working for 56 days. If she does not take 56 days off, the woman must add the days after giving birth to be paid.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.angloinfo.com/how-to/greece/healthcare/pregnancy-birth/benefits|title=Maternity and Birth Benefits - Greece - Angloinfo|newspaper=Angloinfo|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> In Switzerland, a woman is guaranteed up to 14 weeks (a minimum of 8 weeks) of paid leave after giving birth. She is paid 80 percent of her previous wage, with a daily maximum.<ref name=":1" />
=== {{anchor|Iceland, Japan, Turkey, and Slovak Republic}}Iceland, Japan, Turkey and Slovakia === Icelandic women receive 13 weeks of paid maternity leave (with an additional shared 13 weeks), with a ceiling of [[Icelandic króna|ISK]]370,000 per month. Japan allows 14 weeks if the woman is enrolled in the Employees' Health Insurance system. The leave can be taken by both parents in one absence period. There is a minimum payment of [[Japanese yen|¥]]46,230 per month and a maximum monthly payment of ¥285,420. Sixteen weeks of maternity leave are on the condition that the employee was employed for 236 weeks by the 15th week before the first week of leave. There is no ceiling on payments for the first six weeks. [[Slovakia]] grants leave until the child's third birthday as a family entitlement, with a monthly benefit of €203.2.<ref name=":1" />
=== Cyprus, Czech Republic, Hungary, Korea, and Sweden === Women in [[Cyprus]], including women who are adopting, receive 16 weeks of maternity leave. Nine weeks are mandatory, with the first two beginning two weeks before the expected due date. During this time, women receive a grant which serves as maternity pay. After maternity leave, women can apply to leave work an hour each day with pay for six months to help care for their child.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mlsi.gov.cy/mlsi/dl/dl.nsf/dmlposting_en/dmlposting_en?OpenDocument|title=Department of Labour - Employment Policy|website=www.mlsi.gov.cy|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> In the [[Czech Republic]], women receive 28 weeks of paid maternity leave; the minimum leave is 14 weeks. Families can receive financial support for child care. Women in [[Hungary]] have the options of up to 24 weeks of maternity leave at 70-percent pay or financial support and job insurance to raise the child, with part-time work promoted. In [[Korea]], a woman receives 44 days of maternity leave before the birth and 90 days afterwards. During the first 60 days of the 90-day period, they receive full salary; during the last 30 days, they can receive up to [[South Korean won|₩]]1,350,000. [[Sweden|Swedish]] parents receive 480 days of maternity leave, with 90 days reserved for the father. The first 300 days are at 80-percent of pay, and the remainder is paid at a flat rate.<ref name=":1" />
=== Italy, Latvia, Malta, and Romania === In [[Italy]], women receive 80 percent of their normal earnings for six months.<ref name=":1" /> [[Latvia]]n women are granted 114 days of paid leave, which may be extended based on health complications, the birth of more than one child or if there is more than one child under age two. When they return to work, mothers are allowed time to check on their child (or children).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ilo.org/ifpdial/information-resources/national-labour-law-profiles/WCMS_158912/lang--en/index.htm|title=National Labour Law Profile: Latvia|date=2015-09-01|language=en|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> [[Malta|Maltese]] women receive 18 weeks of uninterrupted maternity leave. The first 14 weeks are full salary and benefits, and the last four weeks can be covered by the government.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dier.gov.mt/en/Employment-Conditions/Leave/Pages/Maternity-Leave.aspx|title=Maternity Leave|website=dier.gov.mt|language=en|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> In [[Romania]], women have two options: a one-year leave at 75-percent salary, with a bonus when they return to work, or two years at 75 percent without the return bonus.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lpg-roumanie.ro/en/publications/social/maternity-paternity-leave-in-romania|title=Maternity/Paternity leave in Romania|date=2014-12-19|newspaper=LPG Romania|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref>
=== Bulgaria, France, and Norway === In [[Bulgaria]] women receive 410 days of maternity leave at 90-percent salary, with 45 days granted before giving birth.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.angloinfo.com/how-to/bulgaria/healthcare/pregnancy-birth/maternity-leave|title=Maternity Leave, Allowance and Benefits - Bulgaria - Angloinfo|newspaper=Angloinfo|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> [[France|French]] women are given 16 weeks of paid maternity leave for their first child, and time off increases with subsequent children. The amount paid is based on household income and how many children are already in the family. In [[Norway]], women can choose 49 weeks at 100 percent of salary or 59 weeks at 80 percent.<ref name=":1" />
== {{anchor|Countries Average Pay Rates}}Average pay rates ==
{| class="wikitable floatleft" !Country !Pay rate |- |United Kingdom |30%-39.9% |- |Australia |40%-49.9% |- |Canada |40%-49.9% |- |New Zealand |40%-49.9% |- |Denmark |50%-59.9% |- |Greece |50%-59.9% |- |Switzerland |50%-59.9% |- |Iceland |60%-69.9% |- |Japan |60%-69.9% |- |Turkey |60%-69.9% |- |Slovak Republic |60%-69.9% |- |Cyprus |70%-79.9% |- |Czech Republic |70%-79.9% |- |Hungary |70%-79.9% |- |Korea |70%-79.9% |- |Sweden |70%-79.9% |- |Italy |80%-89.9% |- |Latvia |80%-89.9% |- |Malta |80%-89.9% |- |Romania |80%-89.9% |- |Bulgaria |90%-99.9% |- |France |90%-99.9% |- |Norway |90%-99.9% |}
According to OECD research, 60 percent of countries offering maternity leave do not provide full pay.<ref name=":0" /> The table lists countries offering less than full salary, from lowest to highest.
These pay rates are the average of the paid leave for an individual earning 100 percent of the 2014 national average. In most countries, leave payments are calculated on gross earnings; however, in some—e.g., [[Austria]], [[Chile]], [[France]] and [[Germany]]—payments are based on net earnings (after income-tax and social-security payments). Pay rates in these countries reflect the proportion of net earnings replaced by the relevant payments, and should not be compared directly with pay rates based on gross earnings. Many countries have a variable rate; for example, [[Belgium]] gives women 82% of their salary for the first month. For the remaining three or four months (depending on the number of births) they receive 75 percent, with a cap of €133 per day.
Most OECD countries provide payments replacing over 50 percent of previous earnings, with twelve countries offering average-wage mothers full compensation for the leave. Pay rates are lowest in [[Ireland]] and the [[United Kingdom]], where only about one-third of gross average earnings are replaced by maternity benefits. Despite lengthy paid-leave entitlements, full-rate maternity leave in these countries is only nine weeks in Ireland and twelve in the UK.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oecd.org/els/soc/PF2_1_Parental_leave_systems.pdf|title=Key Characteristic of Parental Leave Systems|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
