{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{hatnote|For her great grandmother, see [[Rose Kennedy]].}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Rose Kennedy Schlossberg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1988|06|25}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in [[English studies|English]]; 2010)
[[New York University]] ([[Master of Professional Studies|MPS]]; 2013) | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | spouse = | partner = | children = | mother =[[Caroline Kennedy]] | father =[[Edwin Schlossberg]] | relatives = [[Jack Schlossberg]] (brother)
Tatiana Schlossberg (sister)
[[John F. Kennedy Jr.]] (maternal uncle)
[[John F. Kennedy]] (maternal grandfather)
[[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis]] (maternal grandmother) | family = [[Kennedy family]] | awards = }} '''Rose Kennedy Schlossberg''' (born June 25, 1988) is an American actress and the oldest child of [[Caroline Kennedy]] and first-born grandchild of U.S. President [[John F. Kennedy]]. She is a 2010 graduate of [[Harvard University]]. Schlossberg has been described as a [[look-alike]] of her grandmother, [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis]].{{cite news|last1=Khoo| first1=Isabelle| title=Celebrity Lookalike: Jackie Kennedy's Granddaughter Is Her Spitting Image|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/03/16/jackie-kennedy-granddaughter_n_9478128.html|accessdate=July 19, 2016|work=The Huffington Post Canada|date=March 3, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Kosin|first1=Julie|title=Jackie Kennedy's Granddaughter is an up-and-coming comedian| url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/culture/film-tv/news/a14640/jackie-kennedy-granddaughter-rose-schlossberg-web-series/| accessdate=July 19, 2016|work=Harper Bazaar|date=March 15, 2016}} In 2013, Schlossberg, along with Mara Nelson-Greenberg, co-launched ''End Time Girls Club'', an [[end time]]-[[Apocalypse|apocalyptic]] [[web television|web television comedy series]] on YouTube.{{cite news|last1=Evans|first1=Dayna|title=End Times Girls Club: Your Guide to Looking Cute As the World Burns Around You|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2016/03/end-times-girls-club-videos.html|accessdate=July 20, 2016|work=The Cut|date=March 15, 2016}} == Early life == Schlossberg was born on June 25, 1988, in the borough of [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state) |New York]], {{cite news|title=2nd Girl for Caroline Kennedy|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-05-09/news/mn-388_1_caroline-kennedy-schlossberg|accessdate=July 20, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=May 9, 1990}} to designer [[Edwin Schlossberg]] and [[Caroline Kennedy]], the oldest and only surviving child of U.S. President [[John F. Kennedy]] and his wife [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis|Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy Onassis]].{{cite book|last1=Heymann|first1=C. David|title=American Legacy: the story of John & Caroline Kennedy|date=2007|publisher=Atria Books|location=New York|isbn=9780743497381|page=xi|edition=[Book club ed.], 1st Atria Books hardcover}}Heymann, 2007, p. 5.{{cite news|last1=Hall|first1=Carla|title=Jackie the Legend turns 60|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1989/07/23/jackie-the-legend-turns-60/b64f3046-30b1-4490-b0f3-109d006e7706/|accessdate=July 20, 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=July 23, 1989}} She was named after her great-grandmother [[Rose Kennedy]], the mother of John F. Kennedy. Schlossberg has two younger siblings, sister Tatiana Celia Kennedy Schlossberg and brother [[Jack Schlossberg|John Bouvier Kennedy "Jack" Schlossberg]].{{cite news|last1=Peterson|first1=Hayley|title=JFK's only grandson, a 20-year-old Yale student, is training to become an EMT|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2285350/JFKs-grandson-20-year-old-Yale-student-training-EMT.html|accessdate=July 20, 2016|work=The Daily Mail|date=February 27, 2013}} Schlossberg's mother is a [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] of [[Irish American|Irish]], [[French American|French]], [[Scottish American|Scottish]], and [[English American|English]] descent, while her father comes from an [[Orthodox Jewish]] family of [[Ukrainian American|Ukrainian]] descent. She was raised in her mother's religion,{{Cite news|url=http://www.interfaithfamily.com/arts_and_entertainment/popular_culture/Interfaith_Celebrities_The_Brat_Pack_.shtml|title=Interfaith Celebrities: The Brat Pack|date=Summer 2008|publisher=[[InterfaithFamily.com]]|accessdate=May 20, 2013|location=Newton, Massachusetts|author=Bloom, Nate}} but also observes Jewish traditions, holidays and holy days.{{cite web|last=Jacobson|first=Aileen|title=A Kennedy Christmas|url=http://www.newsday.com/lifestyle/a-kennedy-christmas-1.541128|publisher=Newsday.com|accessdate=December 5, 2007}} During her early childhood, Schlossberg attended [[Brearley School]] on the [[Upper East Side]] of [[Manhattan]].Heymann, 2007, p. 359. In [[first grade]], she went on a school [[field trip]] to the [[American Museum of Natural History]] accompanied by her grandmother, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. "She was the only grandparent in the group," said a father whose daughter was in the same class as Schlossberg. In 1999, Schlossberg's uncle [[John F. Kennedy Jr.]], with whom she was close, died in a [[John F. Kennedy Jr. plane crash|plane crash]]. == Education and career == In 2006, Schlossberg enrolled at [[Harvard College]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] where she earned a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[English studies]], attended film courses, and became interested in fashion.{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=Andy|title=Things you didn't know about Rose Kennedy Schlossberg| url=http://www.looper.com/12408/things-didnt-know-rose-kennedy-schlossberg/|accessdate=July 20, 2016| work=www.looper.com}} She graduated in 2010, going back to school a year later—at [[New York University]]'s Interactive Telecommunications Program (ITP) —earning a [[Master of Professional Studies]] in 2013. In 2016, Schlossberg co-launched a comedy and [[end time]]-[[apocalypse|apocalyptic]] [[web television]] series with Mara Nelson-Greenberg, titled ''End Times Girls Club'',{{cite news|title=Kennedy kid Rose stars in web show|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BNHB&p_theme=bnhb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_field_fselect-0=&p_text_fselect-0=Rose+Kennedy+Schlossberg+stars+in+web+show++&s_dispstring=all%28Rose+Kennedy+Schlossberg+stars+in+web+show++%29&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no|work=Boston Herald|accessdate=July 20, 2016|date=March 17, 2016|page=15 {{subscription required|s}} }} produced by [[Above Average Productions]].{{cite news|last1=Fogle|first1=Asher|title=See Jackie Kennedy's Lookalike Granddaughter|url=http://www.goodhousekeeping.com/life/entertainment/news/a37390/rose-kennedy-schlossberg-jacqueline-kennedy/|accessdate=July 20, 2016|work=Good House Keeping|date=March 15, 2016}} The series follows two [[twentysomething (term)|twentysomething]] young women, Bee (portrayed by Schlossberg) and Lara (portrayed by Nelson-Greenberg), as they give women comic tips to surviving the [[apocalypse]]. "It came up as a response to seeing the way that New York City responded to [[Hurricane Sandy]], and how people were grossly underprepared – specifically, girls in [[damsel in distress]] mode," Schlossberg told ''[[Mashable]]''.{{cite news|last1=Bueno|first1=Antoinette|title=Jackie Kennedy's Lookalike Granddaughter, Rose Schlossberg, Launches Comedy Web Series|url=http://www.etonline.com/news/184542_jackie_kennedy_lookalike_granddaughter_rose_schlossberg_launches_comedy_web_series/|accessdate=July 20, 2016|work=ET Online|date=March 15, 2016}} "I thought it would be interesting to create this world where girls have to be [[survivalist]]s without compromising their cute factor." == Politics == During the [[United States presidential election, 2008]], Schlossberg donated to [[Barack Obama]]'s [[Barack Obama presidential primary campaign, 2008|2008 campaign]] and volunteered for [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Alan Khazei]]'s campaign for the [[United States Senate]] in the [[United States Senate special election in Massachusetts, 2010|2010 special election]] in [[Massachusetts]]. == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == *[http://www.endtimesgirlsclub.com/ ''End Time Girls Club''] [[web television]] series official website, in which Schlossberg portrays main character Bee. {{Kennedy family |state=collapsed}} {{John F. Kennedy}} {{Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schlossberg, Rose Kennedy}} [[Category:1988 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century American women]] [[Category:21st-century American actresses]] [[Category:American people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American people of French descent]] [[Category:American people of Ukrainian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:Bouvier family]] [[Category:Kennedy family]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:American women comedians]] [[Category:Actresses from New York City]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:American YouTubers]] [[Category:American web series actresses]] [[Category:Brearley School alumni]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 860237181 by [[Special:Contributions/193.187.3.11|193.187.3.11]] ([[User talk:193.187.3.11|talk]]) This is incorrect. Both are used in British English and American English
revision.text:
{{redirect|Netting|the fabric|net (textile)}}
In [[law]], '''set-off''' or '''netting''' are legal techniques applied between persons with mutual rights and liabilities, replacing gross positions with net positions.<ref>David Southern ''Set off revisited'' (1994) NJL 1412, 1412</ref><ref>''Halesowen Presswork & Assemblies Ltd v Westminster Bank Ltd'' [1970] 3 All ER 473 at 488, per Buckley LJ</ref> It permits the rights to be used to discharge the liabilities where cross claims exist between a [[plaintiff]] and a [[respondent]]. The result being that the gross claims of mutual debt produces a single, net claim.<ref>Joanna Benjamin, ''Financial Law'' (2007, Oxford University Press), p264</ref> The net claim is known as a '''[[Financial law|net position]]'''. In other words, a set-off is the right of a debtor to balance mutual debts with a creditor. In bookkeeping terms, set-offs are also known as reconciliations.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} To determine a set-off, simply subtract the smaller debt from the larger.
Any balance remaining due either of the parties is still owed, but the remainder of the mutual debts has been set off. The power of net positions is to reduce [[credit risk|credit exposure]], also holding regulatory capital requirement and settlement advantages, which contributes to [[market stability]]. In regard to the financial market, net positions are vital.<ref>Louise Gullifer, ''Goode and Gullifer on Legal Problems of Credit and Security'' (Sweet & Maxwell, 7th ed 2017</ref>
==Difference between Set off and Netting== Whilst '''netting''' and '''set off''' are often used interchangeably, the legal distinction is made between ''netting'', which describes the procedure for and outcome of implementing a ''set off''. By contrast ''set off'' describes the legal bases for producing net positions. ''Netting'' describes the form such as '''novation netting''', or '''close-out netting''', whilst ''set off'' describes judicially recognised grounds such as '''independent set off''' or '''insolvency set off'''. Therefore, a netting or setting off gross positions involves the use of offsetting positions with the same counter-party to address counter-party credit risk. This is to be differentiated from [[hedge (finance)|hedging]] which uses offsetting positions with multiple parties to mitigate risk.
===Mutuality=== The law does not permit counter-parties to use third party debt to set off against an un-related liability.<ref>P Wood ''Title Finance, Derivatives, Securitisation, Set off and Netting'', (London: Sweet & Maxwell, 1995), 189</ref> All forms of set off requires mutuality between claim and cross claim. This protects property rights both inside insolvency and out, primarily by ensuring that a non-owner cannot benefit from insolvency.
==Market Effect== The primary objective of netting is to reduce systemic risk by lowering the number of claims and cross claims which may arise from multiple transactions between the same parties. This prevents credit risk exposure, and prevents liquidators or other insolvency officers from cherry-picking transactions which may be profitable for the insolvent company.<ref>Finch, Milman ''Corporate Insolvency Law'' (2016, Cambridge University Press, Third edition)</ref>
==Netting== At least three principle forms of netting may be distinguished in the financial markets.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.worldbank.org/finance/assets/images/Woltjer_paper.pdf |title=Risk Management in Netting schemes for settlement of securities transactions |publisher=World Bank |date=March 2002 |author=Jan Woltjer}}</ref> Each is heavily relied upon to manage financial market, specifically credit, [[financial risk|risk]] {{Quote|Since claims are a major form of property nowadays and since creditors are often also debtors to the same counterparty, the law of set off is of paramount importance in international affairs|author=P.Wood|title=''Title Finance, Derivatives, Securitisation, Set off and Netting'', (London: Sweet & Maxwell, 1995), 72}}
===Novation Netting=== Also called '''rolling netting''', netting by [[novation]] involves amending contracts by the agreement of the parties. This extinguishes the previous claims and replaces them with new claims. {{Quote|Suppose that on Monday, 'A' and 'B' enter into transaction-1, whereby A agrees to pay B £1,000,000 on Thursday. On Tuesday A and B enter into transaction-2, whereby B agrees to pay A £400,000 on Thursday. Novation netting takes effect on Tuesday to extinguish the obligations of the parties under both transaction 1 and 2, and to create in their place a new obligation on A to pay to B £600,000 on Thursday.|author=Benjamin,Joanna|title=''Financial law'' (2007, Oxford University Press), 267}} This differs from '''settlement netting''' (outlined below) because the fusion of both claims into one, producing a single balance, occurs immediately at the conclusion of each subsequent contract. This method of netting is crucial in financial settings, particularly derivatives transactions, as it avoids cherry-picking in insolvency.<ref>''Commissioner for HMRC v Entin'' [2006] BCC 955 per Lightman J [21]</ref> The effectiveness of pre-insolvency novation netting in an insolvency was discussed in ''[[British Eagle International Airlines Ltd v Compagnie Nationale Air France]]''[1975] 1 WLR 758. Similar to '''settlement netting''', novation netting is only possible if the obligations have the same settlement date. This means that if, in the above example, transaction-2 was to be paid on Friday, the two transactions would not offset. Novation netting further cannot consolidate obligations. This is a systems intensive process requiring tracking of obligations as they become due.
===Close out netting=== An effective close-out netting scheme is said to be crucial for an efficient financial market.<ref>EFMLG ''The regulation of close out netting in the new member states of the European Union'' 2005, 3</ref> Close out netting differs from novation netting in that it extends to all outstanding obligations of the party under a master agreement similar to the one used by [[International Swaps and Derivatives Association|ISDA]]. These traditionally only operate upon an event of default of insolvency. In the event of [[counterparty]] [[bankruptcy]] or any other relevant event of default specified in the relevant agreement if accelerated (i.e. effected), all transactions or all of a given type are netted (i.e. set off against each other) at [[market value]] or, if otherwise specified in the contract or if it is not possible to obtain a market value, at an amount equal to the loss suffered by the non-defaulting party in replacing the relevant contract. The alternative would allow the [[liquidator (law)|liquidator]] to choose which contracts to enforce and which not to (and thus potentially "cherry pick").<ref>ISDA 2002 Master Agreement, Section 2(1)(a)(iii)</ref> There are international jurisdictions where the enforceability of netting in bankruptcy has not been legally tested.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} The key elements of close out netting are: *default *the accretion of the time for performance of obligations to the time of default *conversion of non-cash obligations into debts; meaning obligations to deliver non-cash assets are converted to market price equivalents; and *set off<ref>See the Financial Collateral Directive (Directive 2002/47/EC, Art 2(1)(n)</ref> Similar methods of close out netting exist to provide standardised agreements in market trading relating to derivatives and security lending such as''repos'', forwards or options.<ref>ISDA master agreement</ref> The effect is that the netting avoids valuation of future and contingent debt by an insolvency officer and prevents insolvency officers from disclaiming executory contract obligations, as is allowed within certain jurisdictions such as the US and UK.<ref>Cf Insolvency Rules 1986 Rule 4.90</ref> The mitigated systemic risk which is induced by a close out scheme is protected legislatively. Other systemic challenges to netting, such as regulatory capital recognition under [[Basel II]] and other Insolvency-related matters seen in the ''Lamfalussy Report''<ref>European Commission,''Report from the Commission to the Council and European Parliament, Evaluation Report on the Financial Collateral Arrangements Directive'' (2002/47/EC), 2006, COM (2006) 833 final, 10</ref> has been resolved largely through trade association lobbying for law reform.<ref>Benjamin, 269</ref> In England & Wales, the effect of ''[[British Eagle International Airlines Ltd v Compagnie Nationale Air France]]'' has largely been negated by ''Part VII'' of the [[Companies Act|Company Act 1989]] which allows netting in situations which are in relation to money market contracts. In regard to the [[Basel_Accords|BASEL Accords]], the first set of guidelines, [[Basel_I|BASEL I]], was missing guidelines on ''netting''. [[Basel_II|BASEL II]] introduced ''netting'' guidelines.
===Settlement netting=== For [[cash]] settled trades, this can be applied either bilaterally or multilaterally and on related or unrelated transactions. Obligations are not modified under settlement netting, which relates only to the manner in which obligations are discharged.<ref>P Wood, ''Title Finance, Derivatives, Securitisation, Set off and Netting'', (London: Sweet & Maxwell, 1995),153-5</ref> Unlike '''close-out netting''', settlement netting is only possible in relation to like-obligations having the same settlement date. These dates must fall due on the same day and be in the same currency, but can be agreed in advance.<ref>Joanna Benjamin, Financial Law (2007, Oxford University Press), p274</ref> Claims exist but are extinguished when paid. To achieve simultaneously payment, only the act of payment extinguishes the claim on both sides. This has the disadvantage that through the life of the netting, the debts are outstanding and netting will likely not occur, the effect of this on insolvency was seen in the above mentioned ''British Eagle''. These are routinely included within [[derivative]] transactions as they reduce the number and volume of payments and deliveries that take place but crucially does not reduce the pre-settlement exposure amount.
::*''Bilateral Net Settlement System'': A settlement system in which every individual bilateral combination of participants settles its net settlement position on a bilateral basis.
::*''Multilateral Net Settlement System'': A settlement system in which each settling participant settles its own multilateral net settlement position (typically by means of a single payment or receipt).
==Set off== Set off is a legal event and therefore legal basis is required for the proposition of when two or more gross claims are netted. Of these legal bases, a common form is the legal defense of set-off, which was originally introduced to prevent the unfair situation whereby a person ("Party A") who owed money to another ("Party B") could be sent to debtors' prison, despite the fact that Party B also owed money to Party A. The law thus allows both parties to defer payment until their respective claims have been heard in court. This operated as an equitable shield, but not a sword. Upon judgment, both claims are extinguished and replaced by a single net sum owing (e.g. If Party A owes Party B 100 and Party B owes Party A 105, the two sums are set off and replaced with a single obligation of 5 from Party B to Party A). Set-off can also be incorporated by contractual agreement so that, where a party defaults, the mutual amounts owing are automatically set off and extinguished.
In certain jurisdictions (including the UK<ref>[[Insolvency Act 1986]], section 323; [[Insolvency Rules 1986]], rule 4.90.</ref>), certain types of set-off takes place automatically upon the [[insolvency]] of a company. This means that, for each party which is both a creditor and debtor of the insolvent company, mutual debts are set-off against each other, and then either the bankrupt's creditor can claim the balance in the bankruptcy or the trustee in bankruptcy can ask for the balance remaining to be paid, depending on which side owed the most. The primary argument This has been criticized<ref>Mokal ''Corporate Insolvency Law'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press 2005)</ref> as an undeclared [[security interest]] that violates the principle of [[pari passu]]. The alternative, where a creditor has to pay all its debts, but receive only a limited portion of the leftover moneys that other unsecured creditors get, poses the danger of 'knock-on' insolvencies, and thus a systemic market risk.<ref>Louise Gullifer, Goode and Gullifer on Legal Problems of Credit and Security (Sweet & Maxwell, 7th ed) 2017</ref><ref>Roy Goode, ''Principles of Corporate Insolvency'' (Fourth Edition, Sweet & Maxwell 2013), 278</ref> Seven still three core reasons underpin and justify the use of set-off. First, the law should uphold pre-insolvency autonomy and set-offs as parties invariably rely on the pre-insolvency commitments. This is a core policy point. Second, as a matter of fairness and efficiency both outside and inside insolvency reduces negotiation and enforcement costs.<ref>Stein v Blake [1993]; Halesowen Presswork</ref> Third, managing risk, particularly systemic risk is crucially. Clearing house rules offer stipulation that relationships with buyer and sellers are replaced by two relationships between buyer and clearing house and seller and clearing out. Effect is automatic novation meaning all elements are internalised in current accounts. Can be in different currencies as long as they are converted at calculation.
The right to set off is particularly important when a bank's exposures are reported to regulatory authorities, as is the case in the EU under financial collateral requirements. If a bank has to report that it has lent a large sum to a borrower and so is exposed because of the risk that the borrower might default, thereby leading to the loss of the money of the bank or its depositors, is thus replaced. The bank has taken security over shares or securities of the borrower with an exposure of the money lent, less the value of the security taken.
===Set-off by Country=== Two primary examples of set-off rules are outlined below. These are in addition to the financial regulations pertaining to netting set out by trade associations and the European Union through the Financial Collateral Directives.
====English law set-off==== Under English law, there are broadly five types of set-off which have been recognised:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.practicallaw.com/4-107-7242 |title=Practical Law: set-off |publisher=Thompson Reuters |accessdate=11 May 2016}}</ref><ref>Roy Goode, ''Principles of Corporate Insolvency'' (Fourth Edition, Sweet & Maxwell 2013), 278</ref><ref>Joanna Benjamin, Financial Law (2007, Oxford University Press), p274</ref>
# '''Legal set-off.''' or '''Independent set-off'''<ref>P Wood Title Finance, Derivatives, Securitisation, Set off and Netting, (London: Sweet & Maxwell, 1995), 189</ref> What is known as statutory set-off, this arises where a claim and a counterclaim in a court action are both liquidated sums or ascertained with certainty. This is wider than insolvent set-off, but the claim and cross claim must be mutual ''and'' liquidated. In such cases the court will simply set-off the amounts and award a net sum. The two claims do not need to be intrinsically connected. # '''Equitable set-off.''' or '''Transaction set-off''' Outside of litigation, where two mutual claims arise out of the same matter or a sufficiently closely related matter ''and'' an injustice would be done if not enforced, the claims will set off in equity.<ref>P Wood Title Finance, Derivatives, Securitisation, Set off and Netting, (London: Sweet & Maxwell, 1995), 189</ref> Both sums must be due and payable, but may be for liquidated or unliquidated sums. Unlike ''Independent set-off'', this is not self-executing # '''Contractual Set-off''' made by express agreement. Often netting will arise through express agreement to the parties, the [[International Swaps and Derivatives Association|ISDA]] master agreement is an example of this type, which is ineffective against an insolvent party but is often used to address pre-insolveny credit risk and reduce the need for collateral. # '''[[Banker's right to combine accounts|Banker’s set-off]].''' or '''Current Account Set-off''' Sometimes referred to as a banker's right to combine accounts, this is a special form of set-off which is implied into contractual agreements with bankers and allows banks to offset sums in one account against another account which is overdrawn from the same client.<ref>''[[National Westminster Bank Ltd v Halesowen Presswork & Assemblies Ltd]]'' [1972] AC 785</ref> However, the right cannot be exercised if one of the accounts is a loan account, or if the bank has agreed not to exercise the right, or if the bank has notice that the sums in the account are for a specific purpose,<ref>{{cite bailii |litigants=[[Barclays Bank Ltd v Quistclose Investments Ltd]] |year=1968 |court=UKHL |div= |num=4 }}</ref> or on trust for another party. It is said to derive from a bankers' lien, however this is misleading as it is only available where both accounts are maintained in the same capacity. Difference in currency will not prevent this right, however.<ref>''[[Miliangos v George Frank Ltd]]'' [1976] AC 443</ref> # '''Insolvency set-off.''' It is perhaps the most expensive form of set off. Under section 323 of the [[Insolvency Act 1986]]<ref>Rule 4.90 of the [[Insolvency Rules 1986]] for companies.</ref> where a person goes into [[bankruptcy]] or a company goes into [[liquidation (law)|liquidation]] mutual debts are automatically set-off. This is a mandatory operation in bilateral situations. Whether the debt is liquidated or unliquidated does not matter, and the set-off will apply to future or contingent claims if the debts are provable. Insolvency set-off operates on liquidation and administration, where the administrator gives notice of his intention to make a distribution.<ref>Rules 14.25 and 14.25 of the Insolvency Rules 1986</ref> The five types of set off are extremely important as a matter of efficiency and of mitigating risk. Contractual set offs recognised as an incident of party autonomy whereas banker right of combination is considered a fundamental implied term. It is an essential aspect for cross-claims, especially when there exits overlapping obligations. Common features of set-off are that they are confined to situations where claim and cross claim are for money or reducible to money and it requires mutuality.
====US law set-off==== {{jargon|date=October 2017}} See De Magno v. United States, 636 F.2d 714, 727 (D.C. Cir. 1980) (district court had jurisdiction over claim involving VA’s “affirmative action against an individual whether by bringing an action to recover on an asserted claim or by proceeding on its '''common-law right of set-off'''”) (discussing similar language of predecessor statute, 38 U.S.C. § 211)
See, e.g., United States v. Munsey Trust Co., 332 U.S. 234, 239, 67 S.Ct. 1599, 1601, 91 L.Ed. 2022 (1947) ("government has the same right 'which belongs to every creditor, to apply the unappropriated moneys of his debtor, in his hands, in extinguishment of the debts due to him' " (quoting Gratiot v. United States, 40 U.S. (15 Pet.) 336, 370, 10 L.Ed. 759 (1841))); see also Tatelbaum v. United States, 10 Cl.Ct. 207, 210 (1986) (set-off right is inherent in the United States government and grounded on common law right of every creditor to set off debts).
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{EB1911|wstitle=Set-off|volume=24|page=703}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} '''Soulieman Marouf''' (born August 1972) is a British businessman.
==Early life== Soulieman Marouf was born in August 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/04074792/officers |title=AL SHAHBA (UK) LIMITED - Officers (free information from Companies House) |website=Beta.companieshouse.gov.uk |date=20 September 2000 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
==Career== Marouf is a friend of the Syrian President, [[Bashar al-Assad]], and has been called his "London fixer".<ref name="thetimes1">{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/world/europe/article4107264.ece |title=Assad’s London fixer is taken off EU sanctions list |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date=3 June 2014 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Robert Booth |author2=Luke Harding |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/mar/14/gilded-lifestyle-assad-coterie-conflict |title=Gilded lifestyle continued for Assad coterie as conflict raged in Syria | World news |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/world/assad-s-british-wife-went-on-harrods-spree-as-his-own-people-died-7573658.html |title=Assad’s British wife ‘went on Harrods spree as his own people died’ | World | News | London Evening Standard |website=Standard.co.uk |date=15 March 2012 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
In October 2012, his assets were frozen and he was banned from travelling in the European Union, the first UK resident to be subject to the EU sanctions against Syria.<ref name="thetimes2">{{cite news|author=Laura Pitel |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/uk/article3579943.ece |title=Soulieman Marouf, Assad’s man in London, is added to EU sanctions list |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date=25 October 2012 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref> This ban was lifted in May 2014.<ref name="thetimes1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Committee Office, House of Commons |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201415/cmselect/cmeuleg/219-xvii/21916.htm |title=House of Commons - Documents considered by the Committee on 5 November 2014 - European Scrutiny Committee |website=Publications.parliament.uk |date= |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
In April 2016, it was reported that Marouf, "owned a number of luxury flats in London held through offshore companies in tax havens, according to the [[Panama Papers]] ... at least six flats across London worth a total of £6m".<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/panama-papers-assad-fixer-soulieman-marouf-owns-luxury-london-property-via-offshore-firms-1553207 |title=Panama Papers: Assad fixer Soulieman Marouf owns luxury London property via offshore firms |website=Ibtimes.co.uk |date= |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== He lives in [[St John's Wood]], London, with his wife and children.<ref name="thetimes2"/>

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2009}} The '''United Nations Public Administration Network''' mission statement is to promote the [[knowledge sharing|sharing of knowledge]], experiences and [[best practices]] throughout the world in sound public policies, effective [[public administration]] and efficient civil services, through capacity-building and cooperation among the United Nations Member States, with emphasis on south-south cooperation and UNPAN's commitment to integrity and excellence. It is organised by the UN Division for Public Administration, part of the [[UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs]].
==See also== *[[United Nations]] *[[United Nations Project Office on Governance]]
==External links== *[http://www.unpan.org/dpepa.asp UN Division for Public Administration]
